150145580.review:
As great as this game is for being what started it all, introducing one of the most satisfying mechanics in GAMING HISTORY, for someone like me whose first experience back in the day was We Love Katamari, this game feels a bit... lacking. And considering We Love Katamari is now available on Steam, I would much more enthusiastically recommend THAT game instead. Mainly for the following reasons:

1) You can roll up all the cousins, but unlike WLK, you can't play as them outside of 2player mode. Bloody love playing as other cousins and considering you can do that in every other game I was surprised and DEEPLY SADDENED this game had no such feature.

2) Compared to WLK, you lose stuff off of your ball a LOT more, nearly every bash against a wall or bigger object results in losing a recently rolled item, and if you're unlucky enough to get stuck (happens often in these games as you may or may not know) you will often have bouts of seeing a SEA of items flying off your katamari as you struggle to break free. This can be especially frustrating if you're trying to find presents/cousins/misc rare items as they can fly off and potentially be lost for that playthrough. Which is DOUBLY frustrating when you have to play through the entire level in order to keep whatever you roll up (except for the Eternal stages where you can quit whenever and it keeps what you rolled up)

Despite those gripes, all in all, it's a fine game, even if just for the fact it highlighted things that WLK did that I previously took for granted. I LOVE WE LOVE KATAMARI. PLAY THAT ONE INSTEAD. Unless this is on sale for £3.99 again like it was when I bought it lmao.

149784570.review:
First and foremost, the Steam version of this game has a bizarre issue where the game [i]forcibly[/i] launches in 720p windowed mode, and you [i]cannot[/i] change this in any way until you finish the opening tutorial. Not even pressing Alt + Enter or any of the F1-F12 keys will work. You [i]must[/i] finish the opening first and get access to the in-game options menu. This is both annoying AF, and yet still oddly fitting with the game's surrealism.

Beyond that, this version is different enough from the PS2 original that I wouldn't sell that version even if you'll end up having both after getting this version. It uses only the Japanese dub, changes the intro song slightly, and adds a new control option that, while still janky, is a lot more accessible than the original where you had to use both analog sticks at all times. Probably why I actually finished the game this time lol

I probably can't say much about the game that hasn't been said millions of times since 2004 or whenever the original came out. It's a weird, joyful experience with a 12/10 quality OST and a cute low poly 3D aesthetic that appeals to me oh so very much.

So yeah, 6/10 port, 10/10 game, definitely recommend as long as that annoying windowed mode thing at the beginning doesn't sound like something that'd put you off the rest of the game.

149681420.review:
Edit: With a lot of effort, some toggling and determination I got the game to work without needing to force close the game. I recommend the game, once and if, you can get it started. While there are some issues (see start in windowed and unable to change settings) it is still fun. You have to accept the short story line, but the real game is going back and trying to beat your previous attempt. Are the controls bad? Yes. The sensitivity of modern controllers makes charge roll damn near impossible. The PS2 version is hands down better, but Bandai is notorious for doing the bare minimum for PC ports. The game is very Japanese, and is a little strange even for that. Considering "Cho Aniki Zero" exists, strange is a relative term. The art, humor and gameplay were unique enough to spawn a series. It was never meant to have success in the west but it has enough charm to fight those assumptions. 

Note: The soundtrack is worth the asking price alone.

You'll spend more time pressing CTRL+ALT+DELETE than you spend actually playing. Just go get a PS2 and a copy of the game. PC port is broken AF. Launches in windowed mode, you cannot change this until after completing the tutorial, as well as the tutorial level. 90% of the time it will not accept the use of controllers. I've found that if you unplug (or power off) your controller when the game loads it will acknowledge it's existence.  You can use keyboard controls, but you'll need an extra pair of hands to do so.
I love this series, but this port leaves me speechless.

149280047.review:
When you first boot the game, it starts in a small, 720p window, with no way to change it to full-screen or higher resolution. One has to go through the tutorial and then beat the first level just to be able to go to the hub world and finally access the options menu where the display settings can be changed.

And let me tell you, beating the first level is easier said then done, as this game's usual control scheme is the dumbest, worst, most convoluted and counter-intuitive that I have ever encountered. And guess what? The game does actually have a normal control scheme to play, and even button mapping option... in options menu! THE SAME OPTIONS MENU YOU HAVE TO BEAT THE FIRST LEVEL TO EVEN ACCESS!

The usual control scheme for this game is so bad, that I have wasted over 5 minutes of my time TRYING TO MOVE at all in the game! It's that bad! And from other comments I have read online, I am not at all alone in this. The tutorial I mentioned above? I feel conflicted if I can even call it that, it teaches you nothing; and I accidentally skipped it by trying to pause the game so that I can access the options menu and change the game's screen-size and resolution. 'It's appalling that a huge company like Bandai Namco were fine with putting their name on a game that released in this state, and has not been fixed five years after release.

Side note: I play the game with an Xbox-One controller, so I don't really know how bad the controls are with just a keyboard, but I understand that they're also pretty bad.

It's sad, really, as the gameplay itself (under normal controls) is really charming and fun. But I just can't in good conscious give a thumbs-up to a game that released in such an insultingly bad state.

149278731.review:
You've likely already played a Katamari game if you're reading this, if not then it's a relatively casual puzzle game where you roll around a ball (Katamari) and pick up various objects; the bigger your ball gets the larger the items you can pick up.

This is a pretty close 1:1 port of the PS2 game; although it has its "quirks". The game will load Windowed initially and I hope you're happy with the sound settings because there's an unskippable tutorial to get through first. I understand the importance considering the games mechanics are based around the unorthodox control scheme but at least allow the basic graphics and audio settings to be adjusted before. Sometimes the game won't recognise my XB1 controller, sometimes I have nothing but SFX and once I had it where it stopped unlocking achievements; all are resolved with restarting but it just lacks the polish you might expect.

As for the game, Damacy is the first in the series and is pretty good but not my favourite - that would likely be Beautiful Katamari as it's the one I played the most. However they're all pretty similar games, this one is just missing some of the extended gameplay you get with later games (don't be expecting to roll up the entire world for example).

Worth picking up, certainly if you're a European like me who never would have had the chance to play this natively due to not being released outside of NA or JP.

148772319.review:
I'm not interested in speaking about Katamari Damacy at great lengths here, but it's not an exaggeration to say that it's an incredible game, and far better than the sequels (yes, better than We Love Katamari, but that is still a good game, and the only other competent entry. It had interesting ideas, but was doomed when tasked with following up this miraculous first entry. The gradual increase in scale that begins with rolling up small things within a house, to rolling up the house itself, and then [spoiler]the whole world by the end, presented as if it all took place on the same map from the beginning[/spoiler] is pure genius, and everything attempted after felt uninventive, derivative, and most importantly failed to match the sheer impact of that satisfying sense progression). 

There was a time before Katamari came out, and a time after; its impact is still being felt in many smaller-scale (dare I say "indie") games to this very day due to its fantastic concept and beautiful, effortless execution. And it would be remiss of me to not mention the intuitive controls that make use of [i]only[/i] the two analog sticks on the controller, but find so many inventive ways to draw different movements out of them. Of course, the game is not without its minor flaws (e.g., sometimes getting stuck is frustrating, and it feels like objects fly off your Katamari if you so much as gently touch a wall) but its sheer originality overshadows most of them.

The above paragraph was referring to the PS2 original from 2004; this is a remake (?) of that title released on different platforms. However, in my experience, the game appears essentially identical, though with the addition of widescreen support and a higher resolution. If any hardcore Katamari veterans would be willing to illuminate me on any significant changes, I would gladly lower my enthusiasm, but as far as I'm aware this is one of the most respectful re-releases of a classic title I have seen in some time and the next best thing to a simple emulated version (which I would still prefer). Anyhow, if you're looking to play this game for the first time, this is a good way to do so. It's just a shame that its brilliant creator will not be compensated in any way, but such is the way of the cruel games industry.

[b]Score: 8/10[/b]

148508098.review:
Katamari Damacy is a short but incredibly sweet one-of-a-kind experience where you play a twin-stick controlled tumbleweed pusher in his quest to roll up everything from the smallest pin to the biggest tower blocks. It took me a few levels to get going, but once it clicked for me & the OST really started to shine, I was smiling all the way through to the final credits. There's just so much charm & attention to detail here that it's hard not to fall in love with the world KD paints.

The only criticism I have is that, despite it running at 144+ fps, it's very clearly rendered at 30 fps, which left me feeling a little bit motion sick on some of the later levels. It's not a criticism, but it's worth noting as well that this is a very short game, though replayability is high thanks to hidden objects & goal-driven nature. 

Wannabe lone wolf-types can only dream of the levels of indifference NPCs in Katamari Damacy display while watching their children get rolled up into a makeshift tumbleweed of plants, random furniture & small animals before getting yeeted into the sky to form a new cosmos. The parents... They must be so proud!

147941128.review:
Not gonna lie, the original 2005 Resident Evil 4 port with keyboard-only controls was more playable than this atrocity.
They should've adopted the alternative modern control scheme from 'Touch My Katamari' where the left stick controls movement and the right stick controls the camera. At least that would translate well into KB+M setup (and even w/o it I wouldn't mind tank controls as much, had the option to map the right stick to arrow keys or num keys was available, but alas)
Instead you're stuck with the classic original tank controls where the "left stick" controls the left hand and the "right stick" controls the right one, and you have to push forward both in order to move forward, otherwise you're spinning in the mud.

Also, not being able to change any controls or display settings (like going fullscreen), until the 10-15min tutorial is complete is the exact thing you should avoid in order to not frustrate your customer (and if your 'customer' forgets to save the game before quitting - they sure will have fun re-jumping through all the hoops agains... Keyboard players especially will have a fun time figuring out the spin-up move without browsing Steam Discussions forum)

TL;DR Nostalgia trip for the fans-only - newcomers will get instantly alienated.

144753921.review:
What the heck else can I say besides the fact this game is always a feel good game and such a fun little activity to set your brain into autopilot. Since owning this on the Playstation 2, I've brought it to parties and any other get together for when people could relax, sit down, and just chat. It's an idle task we all could giggle about and commentate on without being too invasive to everyone's thought process.

With how this game is a feel good game for me, I'm not shy to say these 43.9 hours were sporadic over 5 days and I used the game to feel better in a dark time like I usually have. 100% completion was a fair and fun thing to do, no matter the annoyance on the Ursa Major or Taurus worlds. I popped it on while needing a break from the world and hiding away, but allowing my friends to hop in and watch as I streamed it on discord the whole time. I was able to steer away some pretty dark thoughts and held a game I know always cheers me up, and It was able to also entertain friends while we chatted and made sure I was going to be OK. This is a weird place to praise the game, and I know people may find this review to not be the usual "Little guy rolls things good" or "Lonely Rolling Star" fun, but I feel honesty is needed in stating how special this game is to me. Everyone else may not find the same emotion, the same nostalgia, or the same regard for this game, but this game is so eternal and it always holds itself to the same position it was before. It's age doesn't feel as weird as playing an old NES game you miss and were nostalgic for. When you Pick this up, it doesn't feel like you have to chase any of those feelings. They're right there, you just have to roll them up again.

143311983.review:
There are five games that I would put as being extremely foundational to my understanding of the medium. The first of these, from when I was youngest, was Final Fantasy 1 on the NES. It was not the first game that I played, but it was the first game I Played. As in, it was the first game I recognized as something to be solved, and not a bunch of lights I played with using a little square with buttons on it.
The next of these was Banjo-Kazooie. It drilled into my mind and made me think about it when I *wasn't playing it*. This was an important milestone in my development as an enthusiast of the medium of videogames not just as a game to be played, like monopoly or hopscotch, but as a medium of art.
The third game in that list is Resident Evil 4. I *strategized* for the first time because of that game. It stuck with me, and it informed how I understood mechanics, user interface, how the designers toyed with the player's understanding of the game world. It caused me to not just be engrossed in the world of the game as Banjo-Kazooie had first done, I was for the first time seeing the designers as people first and foremost, with intent and skill.
I say all this as preface to the fourth game that changed forever how I see videogames, and that is Katamari Damacy.
Katamari Damacy is a game that is incredibly dumb. It loves itself for being dumb.
Katamari Damacy is a game that knows that YOU like to be dumb. And it loves you for being you, and for being dumb.
Katamari Damacy is a game that is so full of life, and joy, and heart, and passion, and silly, stupid, idiot, heartfelt powerful delight for you, for itself, for the world, for everything.
Katamari Damacy is a game that loves you. It is a celebration of you playing it.
Every level has a song, and every song, were it to be produced independent of this game, would be an absolute banger of a single that people would unironically listen to in perpetuity.
Every object, every sound effect, every choice as to the form of the UI, every line of dialog, every assembled worldspace, is so utterly joyous and clearly made by people who cared, not just to sell you a product, but to share with you the joy of life itself, that this game should, without a hint of exaggeration, be mandatory curriculum for human development.
When I first finished the final level of the original Katamari Damacy, I believe I was 14 years old. When I realized there there was no more of this beautiful, brilliant, original game for me to play, and that I could not re-experience it for the first time, I stood in my shower under the running water and I wept. In joy, in sorrow, in grief, and in appreciation for what they had given to me.
Would that I could live in a world where everyone was expected to play Katamari Damacy at an age where it would effect them as deeply as it effected me.
Oh, and this re-release did a good job. Whatever.

143055235.review:
[h1] We're Rollin' and We're Boppin! [/h1]

Alright, let me tell you about Katamari Damacy REROLL! This game is an updated version of the classic PS2 gem from 2005, and boy, is it a wild ride!

The story kicks off with "The King of All Cosmos" accidentally destroying the stars. Yeah, I know, it's wacky! So, you play as the Prince, helping the King by rolling a Katamari ball to collect all sorts of objects and make new stars. It's as crazy as it sounds, but that's what makes it so fun!

The controls are simple and easy to learn. You can use a controller for analog for motion controls, but I preferred the good ol' control sticks. Rolling the Katamari feels like building a snowball, but instead of snow, you're picking up bananas, people, and even sumo wrestlers!

The graphics are vibrant and HD, making the world even more charming. As your Katamari grows, you'll start rolling over things that once seemed like part of the environment. It's trippy in the best way possible!

The music is a blast from the past, and if you've played the original, you'll remember the catchy theme song. It's gaming nostalgia at its finest!

Overall, I highly recommend Katamari Damacy REROLL, whether you're a longtime fan or a newcomer. It's quirky, fun, and utterly unique. With better graphics and portability on the Switch, it's a must-play for any gaming enthusiast. I'd give it a solid 9.5/10 for its excellence and zaniness!

142522946.review:
If you asked me to list off my top 5 favorite games this game is a contender for the number 1 position, coming par with long form RPGs that left me changed fundamentally as a person, a la Trails from Zero&Trails to Azure, or short, fantastic experiences like LIVE A LIVE, Hotline Miami 2, or Katana ZERO. At this point this review has been written and rewritten entirely two times just so that I can try to convey what this game is to me. 

This game is a masterpiece and possibly one of the most artistically sound games ever released. There is no other game like Katamari Damacy, and there will never be another game like Katamari Damacy. There /can/ never be another game like Katamari Damacy. I actually get emotional every time I play this game. I cannot make it through the credits without tearing up. I almost make it, too, but when I hear that line, "YOOOOOO--- yagate hikari kagayaku, seiza to nare~" something just takes me over. The spirit of this fucking clump just wells up in me and I lose it. I trip on my words. I laugh. I cry. I send messages to my friends to tell them I love them. And then I play the whole damn game over again.

This game is beautiful. This game is made with love and kindness and hope all rolled into one. If more people could play this game, and really sit down and understand what it truly means, to see each other for who we really are, and recognize that the only thing that truly divides us are the walls we ourselves build, then... I think we could all become beautiful shining stars.

But I think I finished it in like 4-5 hours, and since then I've played the "endless" mode occasionally for the remaining 15. It's really not very good, I"m just addicted to Katamari generally. "Endless" isn't endless at all. This game feels kinda like a mini-version of the best console games.

I'd recommend you get one of the better reviewed games on console if you have one. I only got this because it was the only Katamari on PC, and I don't do console games much anymore.

But if you only have a PC like me, I guess you may enjoy this, but it's not worth $30. Wait for a sale at least.

If this is your first Katamari game ever, you may love it. I have no way to gauge that because I've probably played them all.

141794420.review:
Dear GOD. I came here after getting 100% of We Love Katamari Reroll 's achievements, and, damn, man. You can tell they just ported another console's version of this one and called it a day, with none of the qol stuff that WLKR got.

First off, this one, compared to the sequel, is built for going slow as hell, which, it's kindof fitting that the levels themselves have like 40-30 fps while the prince in the bottom right and the prince's planet are constantly at or over 70. The turn is slow with a weird controller input where, with Simple style, you push the right stick up to have it go right, and down to go left, holding left trigger to make it turn faster, which was fixed in the sequel with quick turn being a single stick press, and, oh boy are you going to be slowly rotating a lot. The levels are huge, empty, and are more focused on exploring rather than quickly growing the katamari, which means that if you come here from the sequel, guess what? You'll be faster than the game was made for and will easily get a maxed katamari with like 3-5 minutes to spare, but you'll also notice how barren, empty, and collectathon it feels while you're doing every level.

Gently tapping anything will send 3-5 objects off of your katamari, leave you stunned for a variable amount of seconds, and will leave you vulnerable to getting hit again, by whatever else is around you, and, unlike the sequel, this one has no no-collide-on-long-hit, meaning you can in fact get stuck in places and easily lose 20 items or more, or get hit repeatedly by something and lose a similar amount. The level design is also jagged, so, when you're trying to climb something like stairs, you'll sometimes randomly bump and lose items because you hit a fragment of some unpolished collision.

There's an achievement for getting all presents, and you're told which ones have presents by the king, but unlike the sequel, you cannot tell which ones have presents left in them by hovering over the level, and, woo did they make them difficult to get, between the easy item loss and where they put them, it's like they didn't want people to actually grab them without specifically knowing when, where, and how to do so. An example is the Crown level. You'd expect it to be somewhere on the ground if you played the second game first, but no. It's being held by a tiny crow at the top of a ramp accessible only from one part of the level, which requires you to be at a certain size and to dash to get it, once you know it's there, through a tiny gap that you can easily bump off of. Yikes.

At least the levels are easily completable, they give so much time if you're coming off of the sequel that you can basically just zone out and get a level done no-sweat, so you can just play to finish it without an ounce of worry.

Cousins are.... So hidden that I literally can't find a single one! I've gotten halfway through at time of writing and I haven't seen a single one somehow.

TLDR: This is VASTLY inferior to We Love Katamari Reroll in every way. Go play that and forget this shitty Xbox port exists.

141643620.review:
Just cleared Katamari Damacy for the first time in years (Since the original PS2 release for me). It was a nostalgic yet very enjoyable experience. I had already started a save awhile ago, but decided to finally finish it up recently. 

Some games and their subsequent franchises are timeless and Katamari is one of those. Particularly Damacy and its sequel [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1730700/We_Love_Katamari_REROLL_Royal_Reverie/]We ❤ Katamari[/url]. [spoiler]Katamari Forever on PS3 while not as good as the Keita Takahashi led duology still gets an honorable mention from me.[/spoiler]

This is a game that uses dual analog sticks to roll stuff up and that's all you really need to know. It's super simple yet very fun and hits those happy brain chemicals. Most levels you're trying to just roll up as big of a Katamari as possible. Other times you have a theme'd Katamari with particular items you need to roll. As well as some other minor challenges. The soundtrack is iconic full of whimsy and joy (Favorite tracks of mine include Katamari on the Rocks, Que Sera Sera, and Lonely Rolling Star). Lastly the remastered HD graphics really bring the cell-shaded minimalist art style to life.

I still need to collect a few more presents and roll up the rest of the items I'm missing in collections then I believe I'll have 100%'d the achievements. All-in-all definitely worth a buy especially if you can get this on sale. I'd also urge you to take a look at [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1730700/We_Love_Katamari_REROLL_Royal_Reverie/]We ❤ Katamari[/url] too since that's just a perfected version of Damacy gameplay wise and just the additional challenge it asks of the player. 

TL;DR - While its sequel is better in gameplay variety and difficulty Damacy still stands the test of time and is a goated videogame. Please play this if you've never had the chance to yet. Also if it wasn't already apparent I highly recommend playing this with gamepad too.

141596439.review:
[b]Remasterización de la primera entrega[/b] de esta curiosa franquicia de nicho que nació en PlayStation 2.

Nuestro padre, el Rey del Cosmos, destruye todas las estrellas del firmamento por accidente y nos encomienda la tarea de [b]restaurarlas[/b]. ¿Y cómo vamos a hacerlo? [b]Pues arrollando todo lo que se nos ponga por delante[/b] en la Tierra con un «[b]katamari[/b]», una bola pegajosa que acaba convirtiéndose en una [b]estrella[/b] o en una [b]constelación[/b].

[b]Controles y premisa simplísimos[/b] que dan pie a un juego de acción/puzles [b]de lo más curioso[/b]. [b]Echa pa'lante y arrolla cosas cada vez más grandes[/b], aunque en las misiones de restaurar constelaciones tendremos que arrollar el mayor número de [b]elementos de un tipo[/b] posibles (como por ejemplo, cangrejos o peces).

Los gráficos simplones pero simpáticos, el humor constante y la [b]maravillosa banda sonora[/b] hacen de este juego [b]una caricia al alma[/b]. Me ha hecho sonreír como un crío. [b]Es demasiado puro[/b].

Lo único que se le puede echar en cara a este título es [b]su corta duración[/b] (lleva unas [b]cinco horas[/b] aproximadamente completar la campaña), pero me parece una experiencia que [b]vale mucho la pena de oferta[/b].

Decidme si arrollar cosas en un mundo tan colorido y simpático con esto de fondo no le levanta el ánimo a cualquiera:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TmzVB_B3ndU

141149319.review:
[h3][b][u]Short Answer:[/u][/b][/h3] A surreal and strangely addicting "roll-em-up" game, one that hasn't lost an ounce of charm since it first launched all the way back in 2004. A faithful remake only occasionally to its detriment, as it still holds on to issues from the original like a fussy camera, wonky collision physics, and an archaic approach to UX (e.g. no autosave, no quick access to settings). With about 5 hours of gameplay, it's well worth your time whether you roll it up at full price or on sale; but don't buy it unless you have access to a twin-stick controller.

[h3][b][u]Long Answer:[/u][/b][/h3] [i]Katamari Damacy REROLL[/i] is a remake of the 2004 PS2 title of the same name, and a very difficult game to properly categorize. When the King of All Cosmos destroys all the stars in a drunken stupor, he orders his son the Prince (that's you) to remake them and restore the night sky. How do you do that? Well, it's quite simple: you float down to Earth with a big sticky ball called a katamari, you roll it around to pick up as many objects and/or living beings in the vicinity as possible, then fling the whole thing up into space so it explodes into a new star--just like 8th grade science class taught me. If it wasn't obvious already, this is a bizarre game across the board, and yet one of the most charming I've ever played.

[b]The first thing that stands out is the artistic elements, which are unique in all the best ways[/b]. Keita Takahashi has a very distinct art style--practical, yet whimsical and humorous, as he puts it--that permeates every aspect of the game, but most notably through the visuals. It's not just in the environments themselves, but everything and every[i]one[/i] that inhabits them--be it from the people or the animals nearby, it's hard to look in any direction and not find something silly going on. The eclectic soundtrack (directed and mostly composed by Yuu Miyake) further adds to the vibe; and its blend of electronic, jazz, samba, and J-pop influences ensures that no two songs are alike. Were it not for Takahashi's and Miyake's creative vision, I don't think [i]Katamari[/i] would be anywhere near as memorable as it is today.

That's not to say that art and music are the only things of note, though--a good game needs good gameplay, after all, and [b][i]Katamari's[/i] gameplay is deceptively simple yet surprisingly addicting[/b]. The goal is to stick objects to your katamari by rolling over them, adding their mass to it and enabling you to snag bigger and bigger objects. The challenge comes from the fact that you can only roll up something if it's smaller than your katamari, bouncing off anything that's too big; and if you hit something you can't roll up too fast (or if [i]it[/i] hits [i]you[/i] too fast), objects attached to your katamari can fly off and decrease your size. You'll have to start with tiny things like thumbtacks and sugar cubes while simultaneously avoiding everybody whizzing past you so you don't crash into them; but it won't be long before you're snagging entire islands full of stuff, or at least feeling the sweet catharsis of rolling up that one cat that kept batting you around when you were the size of a mouse a few minutes ago. It operates off this twin-stick control scheme that can be a bit weird to use at first; but once you get acclimated, it becomes an almost zen-like experience to play.

There are 19 levels total: ten where the goal is to simply make a katamari of a set size within a time limit; and nine that add a small twist, like scoring you based on how much of a specific object you collect. The former are easily my favorite thanks to the sheer spectacle they can provide as you reach ridiculous sizes, but the latter are also plenty of fun since they help make the game feel a bit less repetitive. Honestly, there are only two levels I don't like: "Make Ursa Major" and "Make Taurus". These levels have become infamous in the community, and for good reason: in short, they turn the arcade-y sandbox gameplay into a slower-paced (yet still time-limited) obstacle course, and it doesn't really work. They offer the biggest twist on the core gameplay loop, which I can appreciate; but [i]Katamari[/i] has rather floaty movement that isn't conducive to the kind of precision needed to get a good score here. Luckily, both of these are optional if you're only trying to reach the end credits, and achieving any score on them still counts as completing the level, so you can just try it once and walk away if you don't want to engage with it further.

Overall, it's a really fun game, and one of the few I can say I've replayed many times in both original and remade form over the years. It's not without a few hiccups, though they don't detract from the experience too much:
[list]
[*][b]You have very little control over the camera beyond moving left and right[/b], unable to even zoom out until the game does so automatically, so it can be difficult to see where you're going and avoid obstacles at times.
	
[*][b]The advanced movement mechanics don't work very well[/b]. Dashing is hard to execute and even harder to aim, and climbing just doesn't work half the time because the game will think your katamari is bumping into something and drop you back to the floor mid-ascent. You can get by without dashing pretty easily, but a lot of levels require climbing at some point or another, so it can be frustrating.
	
[*][b]The collision physics will misbehave sometimes[/b]. It's easy to get stuck in places or struggle to get through thresholds, and I once got myself wedged in a way that made the game think I was "crashing" over and over again, causing objects to fly off my katamari until its size got cut in half and I had to restart the level. It's not common, but it's possible.
[/list]

Just to be clear, none of this is the result of a bad remake or a bad port--if anything, it's the result of a very accurate one, because these issues were present in the PS2 original as well. It's almost [i]too[/i] accurate to the original, as [b]there are some useful quality-of-life features missing and some archaic design decisions kept in place[/b]. For example, your settings can only be changed in the level selection screen instead of the pause menu, and it lacks an autosave function as though it's still working off a PS2 memory card. These didn't have a significant effect on my playthrough, but I found it odd that they elected not to change them.

On a related note, [b]the keyboard controls are terrible[/b]. Instead of utilizing the mouse like every other PC title, it tries to mimic the twin-stick controls using WASD and IJKL to make even basic movement is a hassle, not to mention the ridiculous key combos needed to pull off the advanced maneuvers. Talking to a bird in the hub world lets you rebind your keys and even switch to a "simple" control scheme, but it's still not ideal. Using a controller is the way it's meant to be played, but be warned that [b]you can't natively rebind controls when playing on a controller[/b]. You do still have access to the "simple" control scheme to make movement easier, but any other changes you may need for ease of use or accessibility will need to be done externally through something like Steam's controller configuration tool.

If you don't plan on grinding for achievements (which is an ordeal, if you ask me) and just want to play through all the levels, [b]you can expect a full playthrough to last roughly 5 hours[/b]. It's not a long game and the gameplay loop doesn't evolve much throughout, so I can understand if you'd prefer waiting for a sale. Whatever price point you think is fair, though, pick it up once you find it there. [b][u][i]Katamari Damacy REROLL[/i] is surreal, unapologetically silly, just a bit rough around the edges, and an absolute blast to play.[/u][/b]

[quote]For more game reviews, check out my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/42524563/]Curator page[/url]![/quote]

140689061.review:
SteamDeck Performance: 10/10

Katamari Damacy is in an excellent example in simplicity is king. Katamari games offer a unique challenge that feels satisfying and rewarding the more you play. Everything you need to know about this game can be seen on the tin. You roll a ball, pick up things to become a bigger ball to pick up bigger things. That's it. This game play loop is so fun, and rewarding. It will tickle that special animalistic part of your brain that gets pleasure from growing bigger, essentially gaining power. This is also an excellent local remote share experience with friends. Trading off the controller to try and beat your friends personal record during the same session is super fun. The game runs excellently on SteamDeck with zero issues. Highly recommend.

139488620.review:
What can I say? I didn't expect this game to be this good.

The core gameplay is really good, fun, engaging and satisfying.

Also you gotta actively search for the items you can attach to your katamari, because most of the things will be too large or too small (they barely add size, so it's not worth rolling over them), so it's not like this game is any kind of "auto-scroller" - meaning a game that plays itself without asking much of the player.

This game requires your full focus, BUT it's not hard. It's just very engaging - if you don't engage with the mechanics and the gameplay and just want to randomly roll things together into a huge ball without much thinking, then this isn't the game you're looking for.

The levels are very well thought out - as I stated above, you can't just mindlessly roll over everything, you gotta seek the "good stuff". To make this happen the levels are designed in such a way that not everything will be everywhere - sometimes you'll have to go to another area, cause the one you've been rolling for 3 minutes no longer has items big enough to make rolling there worthwhile. And to get to some places you will have to do some "heavy" lifting (it's not heavy at all, but will require a little more oompf to get to). Also, the levels are filled with hilarious items and creatures.

So, the gameplay is really, really great, but the humor and the story are just a cherry on top. The game's pretty hilarious.

Last, but not least: THE MUSIC. It's AWESOME. Just, perfect, rolling is so fun with this music.

Ok, end of review. My score is 9/10, would maybe be 10/10, but the game is rather short: took me 5 hours to complete.

138246954.review:
My first console was an Atari 2600. 

My dad picked one up, complete with a box of games (this was right around when the NES released in the US). Classics like [i]Yar's Revenge, Defender, Pole Position,[/i] and (my favorite) [i]Pac-Man.[/i] I spent [b]a lot[/b] of time with Pac-Man. 

Flash forward a few years; I discover [i]actual[/i] Pac-Man, and it starts a lifelong obsession.

Flash forward to 2004; I am at a party at a friend's house. A dude down in the basement [spoiler]ate some mushrooms and[/spoiler] has feverishly been playing Katamari Damacy for about five hours. I sit down to watch. 

Dancing... Pandas? 
The King... of The Cosmos? 
The music is... [i]amazing??[/i] 
The gameplay is... [i]make a ball???[/i] 

And then... my brain explodes.

[b][i]Oh my God. It's open world Pac-Man.[/i][/b]

I immediately went out and bought a copy the next day. Have been obsessed with it ever since. 

I've got a kiddo now, they just turned three. They've recently shown interest in playing video games. I fully plan on starting them off the way I did -- I hope Katamari makes the same impression.

[b]TL;DR[/b]
Old dork recommends roll stuff into a ball game.

138244686.review:
Kawaii!
Three-quarters of this game is amazing, three-quarters of this game is ludicrously weird. The premise is you rolling over stuff to add them to your Katamari, which makes it grow. If you're bigger you can roll up bigger stuff and so it continues.
The controls are weird, but that's charm. The premise is weird, but that's also charm. The story is lacking, but the King of All Cosmos more than makes up for that. It gets a little repetitive seeing the same areas over and over, but the game is short enough that that's not a problem and the new arrays of items help bring variety.
Pick this up for a short and sweet adventure that'll make a good attempt at being one of the weirdest things you ever enjoyed.

138007084.review:
Katamari Demacy still remains to be a one-of-a-kind series with its initial entry being a must-play. The remaster also does this game justice by preserving almost every aspect that makes it so memorable, keeping it in-line with its original PS2 release. It's unique gameplay and controls allow the level design to expand upon and wrap around itself in ways that I still have not seen many games replicate. The cherry on top is the endlessly charming presentation and bumpin' soundtrack to wrap the experience with a neat bow.

+ Overwhelming charm through visual style, music, story, presentation, and gameplay all (mostly) preserved in this remaster
+ Unique control style with the ability to simplify it

- Somewhat samey gameplay loop with little variety in objectives

136409636.review:
Very chill game. You control a character rolling a ball around, and pick up things to make the ball bigger, which lets you pick up even bigger things. Extremely soulful, weird, and passionate. It knows exactly what it is and it owns it. Damacy REROLL has had a few small changes to the artstyle to reflect a bit closer to the Keita Takahashi's art, and minor time adjustments, don't expect any additional content over the original. Katamari games still put a smile on my face even after growing up with it, and by extension knowing everything that's coming. There are a few more in the series on PSP if you feel like emulating to see more. Just don't expect any toss-ups in the gameplay. There are secrets to find, challenges to complete, and items to collect, but what you see is what you get. The game is fun, very fun if you're bored and want something in your library to shake things up, and it oozes style. In a similar vein to Jet Set Radio, the presentation (especially from its era) still holds up today, arguably better now that its in a higher resolution than SD. I still listen to a few tracks from the OST in my free time. "Katamari on the Funk!" is worth a listen if you are interested, but don't want to buy the game.

My issues are the price, the poor translation to keyboard & mouse, and surprisingly, the requirements. This game is dated with the original release coming out on PS2 in 2004, and the PC version only being released in 2018 because studios are afraid of innovation now, or doing [i] proper [/i] rehashes of old ideas. I expected the port to be harder to run than the PS2 version because of the resolution increase and lack of streamlined optimization due to differences in hardware, but [b] compared to a PS2, [/b] the requirements are very demanding. The main reason it confuses me is because they were able to port this game onto mobile, [b] in 2007. [/b] Do not buy this game if you are on a system comparable to a school laptop. Be sure to check your specs if youre hooked into a toaster.

The main issue with the controls is they were designed to roll a ball around using an analog stick, with your character rotation being regulated to the buttons on the right side of the controller. Since keyboard keys are "on" or "off", the fine controls are much less ergonomic. Its still playable, but a controller makes the game much more enjoyable.

As for the price, I [i] want [/i] to say i'm fine paying full price, but I'm biased because of nostalgia, and I'm aware of the work that must've been done remaking a PS2 game in [b] Unity [/b] of all things. So while I can understand [i] why [/i] the price is as high as it is, the game doesn't have enough content to justify paying $30, especially when you can legally play the original on an emulator for as low as $2. It's just not an infinitely re-playable game. The only time I can recommend paying full price is if you're really interested in what you see, refuse to play any game in a resolution lower than 720p, and aren't willing to jump through a few hoops to emulate.

One last thing to note: "Katamari Damacy REROLL" is the only one available on PC right now at the time of review. The remake of the second game in the series, "We Love Katamari! REROLL" will be releasing in June 2023. That may be worth it at full price if the port is good, and the price is reasonable. [b] "Royal Reverie" is not a new entry in the Katamari series. [/b] It's a set of 5 new harder challenges for "We Love Katamari!". It will also include content only released to PAL versions in the original, with other minor quality of life improvements. Worth checking out if you like this one, but the bonus content will still not justify the price if its priced similarly.

TL:DR: It's worth it on at least a -50% sale, but the game is still a [i] solid [/i] recommend if you don't care about value for money.

Nabbed this game while it was on sale. If I had known it was available on PC any earlier, though, I would have grabbed it full price. 134820109.review:
[h1] Mindless Fun [/h1]

Katamari Damacy ReRoll is a game that was recommended to me years ago and was described as, "A game to switch your brain off and relax." And that description has never been more apt.

The premise of the game is simple, you start off as a little ball and you roll over things to make your ball bigger which allows you to pick up bigger things, until you reach your goal and spiral out of control.

If I recall correctly, this version of the game is a remaster of the 2004 PS2 version, however I hadn't really heard of this franchise growing up and I'm glad I didn't because I don't think I'd have been able to appreciate it until now, even if it is technically a "Kids game."

The art style is so cute and colourful, generally pleasant to look at. Although you can't expect this kind of game to be graphically intensive, especially when you're rolling and collecting what is essentially cities, so don't go looking for "Realism" in this type of game.

The soundtrack is definitely one of the best selling points of this game, it definitely makes you feel good and I'd be surprised if it didn't trigger some kind of dopamine hit in your system, dancing away collecting and rolling about.

This is definitely something I'll revisit when looking to decompress and chill out and overall just make my day a bit better down the line. Oddly enough as well, when I went on steam's store page, I noticed that there's a new one coming out on Steam on the 1st of June, so that'll definitely be a buy for me.

Katamari Damacy ReRoll is a very Japanese game but it's super enjoyable and I don't really see anybody not enjoying it. Sure the controls can be a bit jank at times but I never had an issue completing a mission.

8/10 for what it is - Looking forward to future installments.

134718208.review:
Katamari Damacy is one of the best games ever made, and this re-release of it is fantastic.

I personally feel We Love Katamari is the better game and I can't wait to play it again when the Reroll comes out.

134398117.review:
So you know how Japan has a certain reputation for sometimes being extremely weird and esoteric as? Yeah this is like a poster-child for that. In Katamari Damacy, you play as the harbinger of the apocalypse, collecting the world and all those who live into it into a ball of infinite friction, so your father (who destroyed his own domain of the cosmos over the course of a bender and is shoving his problems onto his son with the excuse that he owes him for giving him life [man emits red flags like a Bathurst marshall on Super2 race day] ) can crunch those aforementioned cities and towns into their component subatomic particles to begin nuclear fusion and create a star anew. This game is fucked up if you think about it, but you don't really think about it often, because you're having so much fun bringing about the apocalypse to Japanese-Clip-Art-Land, and chilling out to this game's absolutely banger soundtrack like  NAA NANANA NANA NA NA NA KATAMARI DA-MA-SHIIIII NA NA NANANA NANA NA NA NA KATAMARI DA-MA-SHI!!!!!!! 

I have a couple of gripes with the game though, and they are as follows;
The control scheme on keyboard is total donkey shite, use a controller like a real yakuza if you can, if you can't put up with it like me, its not thaaat bad once you get used to it. 
There aren't enough levels, this is a VERY short game for the price tag, there are only about a dozen levels split between 3 maps, which is pretty bad. The variety is good though, so its not like you're doing the exact same thing every level. 

Overall, this is a very fun little Japanese(tm) game, its out of the box and very creatively designed put together, I wish there was more to it. The port/modernization otherwise went well enough despite the terrible keyboard port. The soundtrack is easily A-tier, an absolute classic for internet culture nerds and people who have the lack of a life to seek out and play obscure games like this. (btw respect for even being here on this page)

Worth what I paid for it (A7.23), theres still some optional content I need to complete, which should take me to around 7.25 hours of playtime, but the game's quality and uniqueness already makes up for the lost dollar/time ratio.

132668823.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 45.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

132619793.review:
Katamari Damacy is one of the most standout games of my childhood. I'm so happy to have it available on PC and all modern platforms so it doesn't get trapped on the PS2.

You are the Prince of All Cosmos, going down to Earth to collect raw materials to fix your dad's fuck-up erasing all the stars from the sky. There's not much of a story: Katamari is all about it's gameplay after all. It's fun, the premise is wacky, the music is stellar. Length-wise, this first game is a little bit shorter than the sequel that was just announced. At 5-6 hours, it's fine since there's almost infinite replayability, and you can easily close to double that going for 100% on achievements if you don't collect the presents in every level the first time.

There are some nits that I have with the controls. Ultimately, they're just Katamari-isms, but the main thing that irks me is how bad it feels to boost still, after all these years. You have to flick the analog sticks up and down rapidly to charge up the Katamari, but there's little to no feedback to know when it's done charging, and sometimes it takes a second or two to recognize that you want to initiate a boost. In a game with timed stages, boosts can be incredibly important, so it's frustrating not really having them on command. This games stages are fairly forgiving, but if I remember correctly there are some stages in the second game that really make you manage time well.

This is a great remaster, but at $30 I'd say it's a little steep for the ~6 hours of gameplay you get. At $20 or less, it's perfect. Don't skip the game altogether though—there's nothing quite like Katamari Damacy.

[b]8.5/10 - Highly recommended[/b]

This endorsement is conditional. I like the concept, I like the weird stuff the galactic king says in broken/poorly localised English, I like some of the music. However,
- The game will blow your ears out upon launch and you won't be able to fix it for anywhere between 10-30 minutes depending on how well you pick up the controls, because the people who ported this title were lazy.
- The controls are very unintuitive to begin with. So bad, in fact, that I thought maybe steam had screwed up the mapping with my DualShock4 controller. Nope, they're just the controls. You'll somewhat get the hang of it after a couple of levels.

127718199.review:
2004 Was a magical year for experimental game design, and heavy hitting BANGERS. This 6th Generation of consoles with Xbox Playstation 2 and Gamecube were firing on all cylinders when it came to creativity. You had no shortage of a genre to play or felt like any particular style of gameplay design was formed from one or the other like your CoD's or your Assassin's Creeds. Katamari was a game I had heard of once or twice shortly before I evacuated during Hurricane Katrina in 2005.

 I can't tell you how much fun I had playing this, the endorphins of having a modded PS2 library at my finger tips at my 1980 born cousin's house. It felt more like a vacation at the time than a catastrophic natural disaster. I was 13 at the time. I thought I loved games before, but getting closer with my cousin whether it was learning how to build computers with him or mod Nintendo DS's We'd play some ethereal Silent Hill 2 at night after all day playing Burnout Revenge, A Dog's Life, Prince of Persia Warrior Within, REZ, SSX Tricky and Simpson's hit and run or Mr. Mosquito perhaps...

 I found a love for unique game design. But Katamari hit a different nerve, when I heard "You are Smart" while rolling a bunch of matchbooks and thumbtacks and eventually books to kids riding on bikes to cars and gas stations to skyscrapers. I was mind blown and taken back by just how many items were given a "name" and just how i could pick up any of it. 


This game stands out to me as one of the more unique experiences in gaming. I suppose you could say it came out at a time when it affected me on that deeper level while developing an even deeper connection with my older cousin who I'd consider my mentor growing up.  I'd say anyone could enjoy it if they gave it a shot and would find it pretty hilarious or entertaining to say the very least. Give it a go, I got it on sale for $7.50!

127287378.review:
This game is addicting. It's one that I played back on the PS2 in high school, and I remember being mesmerized by the wacky visuals, silly dialogue, and funny gameplay. Being able to roll a ball around an environment that's just overflowing with everyday objects, animals, food, etc. and just see how quickly you can scoop everything up is just as fun as it sounds. It's the kind of energy a lot of junk mobile games try to capture, but they obviously miss the mark whereas Katamari Damacy hits the nail right on the head. 
Coming back to this game over a decade later, I'm just as thrilled by how silly and bright and fun the experience is, and it's such a refreshing break from pretty much any other title I can think of.

Overall, I'd give this game a solid 9/10 for being just an incredible amount of fun that you can pick up and dive straight into. The only drawback of this port is that the controls don't feel as good on a keyboard as they did on a DualShock controller, but that can be solved pretty easily. If you are considering dropping a few bucks on Katamari, I highly suggest you do it!

Listen, it's Katamari Damacy.  You either know about it and you've already made up your mind, or you haven't, in which case buy this game and play it.  It's kind of a short game (if you only do each mission once it's sub-5 hours) but for 30 bucks you get a one of a kind experience and a one of a kind vibe. 125370087.review:
Katamari Damacy REROLL is a remake of the the Playstation 2 game and quite nostalgic, built to be identical to the original Katamari Damacy with cleaner visuals.

The game starts you on tutorial island, an empty area where you learn how to control your Katamari ball. This could be extremely frustrating to a new player since the controls are also a 1:1 of the original, meaning that a controller is highly recommended. Moving both the left and right stick in a single direction moves the Katamari in that direction while moving one of either sticks moves the camera. There are other advanced controls but let's stick with just the basics. Once you learn the controls you hop over to another area where you use what you just learned in action with no time limits, picking up everything smaller than yourself to get bigger and bigger so you can pick up more objects. If you survive that then the story can also start rolling.

One night the King of the Cosmos got drunk and crashed into all the stars, shattering them. The King being scolded by everyone is forced to make all the stars in the sky and forces you, his son The Prince, to help clean up his mess by rolling a Katamari and using those things as as a new star.
Once you complete a level the King of the Cosmos will tell you information about the star you made as well as telling you if you need to do better, you can then replay that level anytime or continue to the next level through the story. Replaying the levels and finding routes to try and get as big as you can before the time runs out is the game play loop. There are also challenge levels that require you to roll up the most amount, or frustratingly a single one item, of a certain object.
Another thing I feel that I need to mention is the soundtrack being incredibly good. Tracks that get you pumped up when rolling, relaxing tracks as well and that opening is so over the top you cant help but love.
The only other complaints I have about the remake besides the controls is that the voice audio is only in Japanese with English subtitles and I don't recall seeing an English voices in the options. Also on startup the volume is loud and will stay that way until you get to the main hub after the tutorial where you can then change the volume and sound effects. However, even after you changed the sound settings and saved a game file, the startup of the game will still be loud until you pick a save file where the sound has been lowered.

Katamari Damacy REROLL is so nostalgic, cute, and quite the fun addicting game and seeing the things that bump you and block your path suddenly becoming a part of the Katamari as you become bigger is very satisfying. The King of the Cosmos, while he can be annoying criticizing you, his requests and dialog are funny, eccentric and off the wall. The game is weird, wacky and there is nothing else like it.

123192280.review:
Rolling up the world is now available in HD and smooth 60FPS+. As the Prince of All Cosmos, you must clean up the mess your father, the mercurial King of All Cosmos, has left after a drunken bender where he destroyed all the stars in the sky.
The game is a speedy play, with not terribly many levels compared to modern games, but it sticks to the original PS2 game and delivers what could be fit into a PS2 disc back in the day.
Most of the assets are remastered in as much HD as the low-poly art style permits, though I did occasionally see a bit of compression artifacts on some of the King's 2D assets at 1440p. The real upgrade for the title is the smooth FPS (and absurdly short load times) possible on modern hardware. Nothing special is needed to run it; this game doesn't use any special shaders or fancy tech.
I recommend a controller for playing the game, particularly a PS4, PS5 or similar controller layout with parallel joysticks, as the game can be a bit awkward using an Xbox or similar controller due to the offset stick locations.
Not much else needs to be said here; it's Katamari Damacy, one of the classic titles from a system which has sold more units than any console to date.
Oh, and the music is great.

122337977.review:
I've never played Katamari Damacy when it originally released, nor was I aware of its success and how important it was to gaming in general from a creative point of view. What did I miss! An amazing gem which manages to capture the most bizarre and innocent feelings. 

[h3]Let's Roll[/h3]
Katamari ultimately boils down to one thing: [b]rolling[/b]. And that's the core concept with the game. Suddenly, a so-called Cosmic God decided do wipe everything from the universe, except for the planet Earth. 

Your job, as the 5-centimeters tall Prince, will be to gather things on earth through your "katamari", a ball which grows larger and larger and eventually lets you pick up enormous objects as you go on. That's it! And I think that there's a lot of depth in its simplicity, even though commands are a bit clunky, in my opinion.

There will be some variations in level structure throughout the game, such as "roll up the biggest cow" or something similiar, to differentiate what ultimately will be you rolling and collecting stuff.

Overall, I've found the whole rolling part extremely relaxing. I recommend using the controller to move around, because of the clunkiness cited above.

[h3]In The Zone[/h3]
There's that sort of [b]Japanese Arcade Game[/b] feel, and I couldn't be happier about it. I can't put my finger on it: it may be the animations, the art style... the jazzy, fluffy music in the background. 

The whole package screams creativity and originality, since the main protagonist will be instantly recognizable from the very moment you boot up the game. Everything has an innocent, blocky design and overall is very simple. I can see why this game manages to do well in terms of performance.

Even though I didn't say much about the music, there's a lot to appreciate there too. The warm, jazzy, cozy feeling of almost childish songs in the background made the experience unique and, to be honest, pretty much replayable.

[h2]Sending Love To The Prince[/h2]
I felt very relaxed. 
Every aspect of Katamari Damacy made me fell in love with it, and even though this wasn't a lengthy review, I highly suggest this game and I think it'll fall under my favorites easily. 

Just as [i]Wattam[/i] is making me feel the most basic, inner feelings... so did Katamari. 
The gameplay is simple, and may be a bit repetitive, but its length isn't going to make you feel so, since you'll complete it in roughly 5 hours. Plus, as I've said, there are some variations on different levels.

Play it and you will not be disappointed. Great game!

122307650.review:
[b]Quirky gameplay coupled with fantastical characters and music make Katamari Damacy Reroll a no-brainer for those curious of the absurd. Controls can take getting used to but once you're in the zone, the game delivers in spades an experience unlike any other.[/b]

+ gameplay like no other game you've played before
+ absurdist humour is a delight
+ trying to beat scores incentivizes replays
- very short game with very few levels
- levels are not particularly varied enough

[h1]Full Review[/h1]
Katamari Damacy is a puzzle game, tasking you with sticking objects you find around the world to your katamari, a ball you roll around. Each level starts off at a micro scale and slowly your katamari becomes bigger and bigger, going from picking up dominos and pushpins to ripping out the ground underneath you and scooping up buildings.

While there is a story here, it's not really important. It relies on inane and absurdist humor, which adds to the charm and allure to the game. However, the game doesn't really need a reason to keep you playing other than by the laurels of its gameplay alone. It's very satisfying watching your katamari go and when you get into that state of flow and everything seems to run autonomously, it's thrilling in a way that a game this simplistic normally wouldn't deliver.

The controls are simple to learn but difficult to master. There is absolutely a learning curve and you will frequently fight with the controls, especially the larger your katamari gets. As well, there were a few instances of my katamari getting caught on world geometry; watching my katamari just melt away because of the sometimes wonky collision detection is frustrating, but was infrequent enough that it wasn't a huge deal.

The game is a little anemic on content: there are 20 levels, 10 of which range from 5 to 30 minutes to complete, and the remainder have more flexible completion conditions. If you don't count retries or failures, the game can be completed in only a few hours. There are endless modes and treasures to collect padding the game length but a casual playthrough will be very short.

All that said, those are just numbers and they discount the fun factor of the game: you'll want to play it again and again because of its charm, humor, and just solid gameplay. It's a very pure videogame with everything else tangential to the gameplay. Even if I've completed it, I often go back to replay levels because it's designed so well and can be played casually while still being fulfilling.

[h1]Steam Deck Specific[/h1]
With the few settings available cranked, 60fps can be maintained, even at as low as 4w, giving ample battery life. Game runs great with a flat frametime graph, it's exceptionally solid with zero dips or fluctuations.

I always found Katamari games to be capable of skirting the line of controller abuse: I would keep that in mind when playing on the Deck. Some moves you can do in the game require rapidly alternating directions on both analog sticks at once, and at all times you are using both analog sticks. The analog sticks are used here to a much higher degree than most other games, so analog stick longevity could be a concern. Your mileage may vary.

122295351.review:
Don't bother if you're planning on using a mouse/keyboard.  You have to use the keyboard like a dual controller - eg you have to hit w and i at the same time to roll forward, and a lot of other ridiculously over-complicated and non-intuitive combinations.  You have to struggle through the entire irritating tutorial (where they teach you how to use the key combinations but don't *explain* how to use them, so I got stuck a couple times not using the combinations in the exact way and for the exact amount of time the game wanted them used) to get to the settings in order to change to what is called 'simplified' controls.  At which point you can at least use wasd for movement, KIND of - but you still have to use right hand keys for turning, etc, and it's so slow to use that it's impossible to navigate naturally, you just run in one direction, slam into things, angle a bit, back up, angle more, back up, get hit by something else that snuck up behind you, slammed into a wall... in short, yes, I'm going to ask for a refund for this unfun, unplayable game.

If you have a keyboard I recommend The Wonderful End of the World instead.  It's got its own pros and cons, but at the top of the pro list is a much, MUCH better mouse/keyboard control scheme.

122180540.review:
Overall, this is a good port (more like a re-write, since I doubt the original game was written for Unity). Better than Crysis Remastered for a start -_-

The whole game is there and its totally stable. The art and cutscenes look great in 4K. Katamari Damacy continues to be one of the most reliable games for inducing general happiness.

A couple of niggles, which in the grand scheme of things aren't that big of a deal but should have been addressed:
-The game launches in a 720p window and you can't change it until you complete the (very short) tutorial. This is bizarre. There is also a bug where the main game will not actually change resolution until you restart the game (until then, the main game window is just stretched 720p, while other elements will be 1080p/4k). Until I learned that restarting the game would set the proper resolution, I was planning to return the game over this.
-While the framerate is unlocked, many things (including the Katamari) operate at a locked 30 fps. This can be quite jarring, when you get used to general 30hz and then the king moves the camera at 120hz.
-No auto-save. They warn you about this to make sure that you manually save, but one does wonder why auto-save was not implemented.

119771110.review:
It is the definitive roll-stuff-into-a-ball game, but I only recommend this game on deep sale or in a bundle to people who enjoy the concept and don't mind the low detail graphics & 30 FPS inherent in this PS2 port.
Here is what you need to know:
-This is a port to Unity of the original PS2 game. Although all cutscenes are definitely HD quality and you can use any resolution after playing the tutorial, you will be locked at 30 FPS, and the textures aren't very detailed. None of this makes the game less enjoyable than the original, but it will be jarring to anyone who plays modern 3D games at 60 or more FPS.
+Music, sounds, and cartoonish look all work together to create childlike wonder.
?Stuff can get repetitive by the last few levels after 3 hours in, especially if you don't alternate between stars and constellations, though the ball size of the last level has some extra uniqueness that makes it worth it.
-Music and SFX volume level settings do not take effect until your save file is loaded.
-Saving must be done manually, just like the PS2 game. There is no reason not to save the game after completing each level, because even after the final level all cutscenes, levels, and credits can be replayed.
+Aside from the limitations of the port, it is otherwise polished from a functional perspective, controller controls worked well, and I did not encounter any bugs.
?Evidently a controller is recommend for this game, and it can be really tough to control with keyboard. I haven't used anything other than a controller.
?Keep moving forward when possible, as going backward is slower.

118977331.review:
Katamari Damacy isn't just a unique game, it's its own cultural phenomena. Like Jet Set Radio, its sense of style is unique even today, and half the selling point.

	To understand Katamari's initial appeal, I think its pertinent to know the time period it was released in. Japanese cultural exports have been around since the 80's, but around 2004 (Katamari's US release) it was still a relatively fresh well to drink from. I'd say that the 10 year span from '95 to 2005 was where most millenials got their 'taste' of Japan's pop culture (mostly anime and J-pop). By now (2022) their culture is so normalized that it isn't difficult to get an anime recommendation from a young mainstream celebrity or rapper. And I'd argue that Katamari would not have as outlandish an appeal today as it did 20 years ago because of it.

	I'm not arguing that Katamari Damacy is this 'landmark' achievement in Japanese history and culture. But for its time, it was certainly another 'uniquely Japanese' item for the burgeoning American sub-culture. Especially if your main consumption medium was gaming.

	What makes Katamari uniquely Japanese (aside from its development studio) is, most obviously, its soundtrack. Japanese vocals, in the 'Shibuya-Kei' style of music: an eclectic and quirky mix of light-hearted jazz/sambo/electronic music. Coupled with the music was its art direction, which emphasized bright and solid colors. Pleasant and serene everyday environments are portrayed with a level of quirky oddities that underlie its sense of humor. Sumo wrestlers bike with bears by ponds. Humans sport cube-shaped heads with static expressions. The King has a stoic and chiseled face whilst posing fabulously in tights. 

	It's a focused package that emphasizes light-heartedness, qurikiness, and an innocent sense of humor that creates a whimsical world. It's not that these ideas are outside the scope of imagination for Westerners, but its a Japanese invention that emerges from the colorful and serene creations of its home country. So unique is Katamari's style that it was exhibited at the NY Museum of Modern Art, which is no small feat. 

	It all makes sense when you learn that the director and creative head of the game-Keita Takahashi-was a former art student who worked in Namco's art department. 

	I spent all this time talking about the game's art and music, and describing how unique it is, because its half the selling point. With Katamari being so bizzare and unorthodox, there was hesitancy on the part of Namco to bring it to the West. And rightfully so: 2004 was the year of Halo 2, MGS3, Gran Turismo 4, Paper Mario, and Metroid Prime 2 (phenomenal year btw). Katamari is absolutely nothing like these games in tone, content, or artistic style. Even if you shove aside the superficial, the game itself plays nothing like anything before it.

	You roll an adhesive ball (a 'Katamari') around picking up items, growing larger and larger in the process. The only challenge is an arcade-like one: get the largest Katamari within the specified time limit (score recorded at the end). About the only unique level is the one where picking up a bear (of any size) ends the stage; you spend the time trying to pick up anything but bears to get a large enough size to roll up the largest bear. The game is very arcade-like: an extremely simple concept to pick up, with very little nuance. Supposedly Namco kept pushing for more complexity, but Keita pushed back.

	Luckily the game came out in the west, and to high marks. There was initially a low print run, since sales expectations weren't high. Given the landscape, sales expectations weren't high. It didn't move anywhere near Madden or Halo numbers, but it became a 'cult' hit with its ardent fanbase that slowly grew. Katamari's appeal is arguably stronger in the West due to it being that much more bizarre here. In the same way an American movie might have higher ratings in Japan because its foreign and different.

	Critiques that have existed since its release are that you are essentially doing the same thing level after level. That there are only really around 5 levels (stages are re-used with each subsequent one openinig up more of the level/altering stage items). That the game can be completed in under 6 hours.

	All true. Which is why I say that its unique style is half the appeal. If you can appreciate the music and odd world, you're getting more mileage out of this. Katamari is a video game that can be argued to double as an art piece. To the games credit, even disparaging reviews admit that the rolling aspect is 'fun for a while'. So even if you're blind and deaf (but can still somehow play the game itself) there's some enjoyment there. 

	I'd call it a classic. One of the 'must plays'. It's aged terrifically due to the art style (much like Jet Set Radio and Windwaker). There's nothing complex or intricate about it, but there doesn't have to be. There's an effective game loop, with some levels having a massive sense of scale that is emphasized when you start rolling over the skyscrapers that looked so huge 8 minutes ago. Hopefully they stop ignoring the second game and port that one as well.
