118914608.review:
This review is coming from someone who hasn't played the original title so I cannot do a comparison between this and the original to see what's the better version. This title is a remake of 2001's Katamari Demacy, released for PS2, published by Namco (before the Bandai merger). 

In the game, you play as The Prince who is tasked to restore the stars of the galaxy after his father, The King of All Cosmos, accidentally destroyed all of them.. The objective of the game is to simply roll up objects on Earth to increase the size of your katamari ball to grow it bigger to roll up even bigger objects you normally couldn't before - these will end up being used as star replacements. Running into objects too large can knock you around and potentially knock objects off your katamari so it's important to avoid them as much as possible until you can roll them up, and some objects will intentionally come after your katamari or attempt to flee if they realize they can be rolled up. You will roll up things like: office supplies, toys, animals, furniture, people, cars, boats, buildings, giant monsters, and even god himself. You're supposed to reach a certain katamari size goal within the time limit, otherwise you will be scolded by The King of All Cosmos, and will have to replay the stage before continuing. If you reach the size goal before time is up, you will proceed as normal, but your asked to make it as big as you possibly can with the time left over - this makes the game an arcade-like title. There are also presents to roll up in almost every stage for a new cosmetic item for your player character, and there are additional stages with different objectives like: roll up as many crabs as you can, roll up the biggest bear, and make the katamari ball as close to 10 meters as possible without the tool to tell you the current measurement.

As I'm sure all the other reviews mention this, the game is certainly unique. While there have been a couple titles that I can think of that have taken inspiration from this title, they honestly don't do it as well. Rolling up objects that were once giving you trouble before is always satisfying along with rolling up buildings and hearing the individuals inside scream (I know it's weird to say, but it is entertaining). Also, the presentation is still pretty interesting, and the music will stick to you as well. The game's cutscenes don't really focus on the two main characters, but show the perspective of a random Japanese family during this strange time, most likely to give you an idea of how humans on Earth respond to this, and to crack jokes. Before and after each stage, you see The King of Cosmos talk to his son, and the man does come off as strict and maybe unintentionally verbally abusive as he questions whether or not you are adopted since you are so small and tells you he was playing catch with one of your royal presents just to name a few things.

The only criticisms I could think of for this title is the lack of variety, getting the katamari stuck, and, in the rare instances you fail, it sucks cause you might have to redo up to 25 minutes of work (again, it's rare as you really just need to learn level layouts and understand that you need to roll up bigger and bigger objects and not just small ones to succeed). And I'd recommend picking this version of the title on sale cause as far as I'm aware, there is no new content here aside from I guess the higher-resolution graphics. I think they could've bundled in We Love Katamari, the sequel to this title, as well as it plays off of this title and improves some of my nitpicks from the looks of it.

tl;dr fun title, unique presentation and gameplay, good music. Could use more variety, and getting stuck or setback can be annoying. Would recommend to pick this up on a sale.

Remember when life was fun? When you just did things? Not even thinking about them, you just DID THINGS. And it was great.

You'd swing on the swing because it was fun. You'd dig in the dirt because it was fun. You'd play with action figures or dolls because it was fun. You'd throw things because it was fun. You'd run fast because it was fun.

It was fun because you were young, and you were a kid, and your mind wasn't developed. It was fun because the world is designed for fun. Everything here is ostensibly awesome, and experiencing all of it is objectively cool. You understood that as a child. Adulthood robs us of that innocence, of that silliness, of that lack of caring about anything in the name of fun.

This is that. This is fun. This is "make ball big" fun. It doesn't need a point or a deeper meaning. It's just fun on its own. I will be sad if I never experience something this fun again.

117936843.review:
Never having played it when it was first released, I got to try out this remastered version as a gift from a friend. All I can say is, I've been missing out! For a quick summary, you play as the little Prince. Your father, the King of All Cosmos, destroyed all the stars in the sky in a stupor. So, like the loving, responsible parent he is, he tasks you, the child, with fixing it. Equipped with your katamari, you must roll up all the stuff you find on Earth to grow your katamari's size in order to make new stars. (Said stuff can include chairs, plants, animals, food... people. My, Earth is full of things.)  

This game is ridiculously adorable and charming, with a unique style and absolutely banger soundtrack. The first negative thing people would tell you is that the controls are rather difficult and take some getting used to, but I think that's part of the experience. Especially with how large your katamari can grow, it kind of makes sense it would become harder to control. The power trip that comes with rolling up buildings is immaculate.

All and all, fantastic game! Whether you're like me and are experiencing this series for the first time, or you're a fan of the original game, I say Katamari Damacy REROLL is a fine addition to anyone's steam library.

I had been eyeing this game for about a year. I had seen some game play from the game grumps on youtube and was really curious about katamari. So It went on sale on the Playstation store back in April and I ended up buying it. Easily one of the best video game purchases I have ever made. Katamari Damacy is probably one of my favorite video games I have ever played (Which is saying something because the sequel We Love Katamari is even better). There is so much good about this game. The simple but funny graphics, the interesting controls, the absolutely unbelievable soundtrack, I could go on and on about all of it. It's not a long game, but it's extremely replayable. The main concept of katamari is controlling a little green man named The Prince who pushes around a strange looking ball called a katamari. With this ball you pick up objects to grow in size to reach a certain size to clear a stage. These objects range from thumbtacks, birds, cars, buildings, and even whole islands. The concept sounds very weird but trust me, it's extremely addicting once you get the hang of it. Some levels go beyond just growing in size. For example, One level has you picking up a bunch of fish to make the constellation of pisces. Another constaliton level has you picking up swan eggs to make the constellation of cygnus (The game has a lot of stuff about zodiac signs and stars and constellations). Since this game is very hard to explain, I would just recommend buying it. While some people say its not worth the 30 dollar price tag due to its length, I would say it's worth every penny, But that's mostly because I love this game to death. So I would say you could either just buy it or wait for a sale, it's your call. But I loved this game so much that I bought it a second time for sale on steam. 

SCORE: 100/100

P.S. Bandai Namco, Please make a We love katamari Reroll. Please, I am begging you.

Katamari Damacy REROLL, a 4-30 hour colorful and quirky game where you roll up objects to restore the stars in the sky. Levels are around 10 min each and the game can be completed very quickly, start from rolling up small household items, to entire towns. Create constellations, occasionally collect gifts from the king, and explore and discover new things in the world.

115181446.review:
I remember playing this back when it launched in 2004 for the PS2 and thoroughly enjoying it. When I first heard this one would be rereleased in steam I didn't hesitate, but completely forgot about it until a few days/weeks ago. Suddenly nostalgia hit like a semi truck and I was hooked once again.

Gameplay wise, it is still the quirky, addictive gameplay, filled with absurd humour everywhere you look, and it's a blast.

Port wise, it's a bit of a mess; graphics settings are nearly non-existant, they haven't really bothered tweaking the engine to make it run better so you'll still see the same performance as before. They've added some cheap ambient occlusion, and that's it, and the resolution choices are poor at best, with some weird scaling artifacts. The controllers are the same as they were back in the PS2, but I can't really imagine this being played on KB+M, it would probably suck.

Even with all of that said, the game is a blast, and will probably run on a toaster. It's about 4 hours of fun, well worth the time. Now I just hope they release the rest of the games.

115165229.review: I somehow missed out on this series my entire life, but was happy to give this a play on Steam. It is fun and weird, maybe the original meme game. It has some hidden depth that modern meme games (I am mostly thinking of Untitled Goose Game) do not. It is somewhat frustrating at times but really satisfying to play. The built-in mechanic of building up your katamari and obliterating stuff that got in the way in the beginning never stops being fun. The story is also goofy fun but take it or leave it. It has some elements to encourage replay but this is still a relatively short and light game. Unfortunately it also once it really starts to get going. Apparently the sequels pick up where this one leaves off but, well, they are not on Steam or any other modern system. I think the price is a bit high for a pretty barebones PS2 port, but I can say with total confidence that Katamari is a totally unique experience you cannot get outside this series.

115150575.review:
Katamari Damacy is one of my definite PS2 favorites, but it hasn't aged quite that well. First of all, Namco put no effort into this port as it starts up in 1280x720 windowed and you have to finish the tutorial before being able to access settings. This is just insane.

It's a one time annoyance, but it's super annoying. The second thing that I don't really recall being that annoying were the controls. In certain situations it's rather unwieldy and cumbersome. Of course, sometimes that's down to the katamari being what it is and the physics involved, but it was still frustrating. Another thing I found annoying was how rather small bumps would cause my katamari to come to a screeching halt and sometimes I would get stuck and just desperately watch how half the stuff would fall off my katamari. I guess back then I had a slightly higher tolerance for this stuff.

Disregarding all that, this is a wonderful, wholesome, bizarre, fun game that is still unlike anything else. Just slightly less playable in 2021 for a man in his late 30s.

7 OUT OF 10

114535890.review:
This is a remaster of a PS2 game that was released in 2004. It holds up strongly in today's gaming industry. Namco created a timeless classic through the use of their stylized and eye-catching graphics. Colors are vibrant and bright without being too saturated, shapes are well defined, no texture pop-in and maximum draw distance. Ailising is not a problem either. They are very appealing as you won't see this kind of art commonly. The music is absolutely memorable with its friendly but strong vocal soundtracks. There is chanting and full lyrics with a mix of singers. The game has a simple control system that doesn't take too long to learn while being a part of the difficulty (skill ceiling). The story is very simple which is fitting for a game where you just dive in and have fun. 

The port doesn't add new content unfortunately, albeit it is faithful. You can't play as other cousins (characters) in single player mode as you could in the sequel PS2 game without mods. The camera still suffers but it is nothing unplayable. Aside from missed opportunities the one flaw of the port is that it boots in windowed mode, but you can change this.

The story can be done in about 3 hours without repeating anything, but there is plenty of side content which can extend this to around 6 hours. There isn't a ton of different stages but they differentiate between them enough to keep things always interesting. Trying to outdo your times and records creates incentive for competition as well.

Overall this game is a no brainer to pick up on sale and still worth it for retail if you want to play something mesmerising and soothing. Anyone of any age can play this and have a good time.

Let's be honest: this port is about as lazy as can be -- for example, the fullscreen option is buried behind the controls menu (because the Playstation version didn't have a concept of switching screensize or resolution) and is disabled by default until you get through the tutorial. 

But it's a testament to the sheer joy and genius of Katamari that this port is still a lovely and fresh experience, everything from the entire concept to the flavor text to its brilliant soundtrack, even many years after its PS release. If you've never played it before, it's an auto-buy -- especially for 66% off ($9.89 on Apr 25, 2022 daily sale). 

Here's hoping that Namco will eventually port its superior sequel We <3 Katamari

111884708.review:
Overall:

Katamari Damacy is one of the most unique, viscerally fun, conceptually and artistically beautiful games I've ever played. Its simple, yet engaging gameplay, its hilarious writing, gorgeous art style, and catchy music are sure to charm any gamer, hardcore or casual, as long as they are open minded enough to engage with something a little outside of the box.

9.5/10

The good:

Katamari Damacy is a game about pushing a giant sticky ball, (called a Katamari) around while gathering more and more objects that stick to it, growing its size, and allowing bigger objects to stick to it, wreaking increasing amounts of havoc. It's basically a score based arcade game, where you try to get your Katamari as big as possible under a time limit. While that may sound fairly boring, Katamari Damacy makes it fun and exciting by engaging through its genious design and art. Rolling the Katamari around is handled by using the analog sticks on a controller (please don't play this on a keyboard, it's not as fun), each controlling one of the Prince's hands. This unconventional control scheme takes some getting used to, but it provides a very "realistic" feeling to controlling the action on screen. You really feel like a small guy trying to push a giant ball, with an increasing intertia, as more things get stuck on it, and it gets heavier. You start off in an open level by pushing a light, small Katamari, picking up pins, pencil erasers, small sweets etc. Getting hit by something bigger, like the house cat, causes items stuck to your Katamari to become unstuck fly off, so you really need to be careful in what you try to pick up. As you pick up more things, and the Katamari gets bigger, you can pick up bigger and bigger objects, including the house cat that gave you trouble earlier. In the later levels you can find yourself wreacking havoc with a ginat hard to control Katamari, picking up entire city blocks, trees, and Godzillas. This slow progression from a place of vulnerability to one of absolute dominance over one's environment is an inherently satisfying power fantasy. The visuals are colorful and vibrant, full of Japanese quirk and charm. There are tons of objects to be picked up in each level, both still and moving, but the art style's simplicity keep it from being visually overwhelming. The music is upbeat, high energy pop perfection, blending different styles from jazz and samba to electronic and J-pop in very imaginative ways. It is also incredibly infectious, and it fits the tone and gameplay rhythm perfectly. Finally, the game's writing (what little there is of it) is hilarious. The King of All Cosmos, the main character's father is a very efficiently written character, with his incompetency, self centeredness, and open disdain for the Prince becoming lovable traits through his cute and flowery dialogue. Thematically, the game serves as a satire/critique of consumer culture, where you're trying to collect as much stuff as possible, your efforts do so are never enough, and you're destroying everything around you to do so. This dark undertone of the game is presented subtly, and adds a layer of depth to something seemingly juvenile and meaningless.

The meh:

The number of different levels in this game is fairly small, as the same environments are reused for challenges at different scales. That is excusable, and something the later games in the series would improve upon. The gameplay. while absolutely fantastic, as described in the above section, can become a little samey after a little while, and not for a lack of effort. Some challenges are centered around picking up as many objects of a certain kind as possible, or picking up the biggest object of a certain kind you can. These are fun, but I wish the game did a bit more to diversify the gameplay. Finally, while the gameplay allows for some interesting challenges, the ones set by the game are very easy to complete, with ample time being given for each one. There's also no incentive to get higher scores than the ones expected of you, not even a high score board. I realize that this is probably by design, as Katamari is designed to be an aggressively accessible, and pretty laid back experience, but I wish there at least was an option for higher difficulties.

The bad:

I honestly can't think of anything particularly bad about this game. It's nearly perfect in my eyes, and my only gripes with it are so personal and so minor that I can't explicitly call them bad.

111137669.review:
Katamari Damacy is a classic. It's a quirky Japanese game with an amazing soundtrack, a cute and colourful world, a strong sense of humour, and all rolled up together it's a perfectly fun G-rated game and an antidote to depression. 

You have to roll your sticky ball, a katamari, into everything with it's momentum to make it grow as big as you can get it. What separates this from your average pacman clone is that you have a fully realised 3D world - and your ball can only pick up small things before it can grow big enough to pick up bigger things. Trying to pick up things before you are able to will knock something off your ball and slow you down - wasting time. What you choose to pick up and where on the map you choose to go is part of the game's strategy - in addition to trying to control a rolling ball and it's momentum from many of the zany things on each map.

Keyboard controls on the PC game will take some getting used to: WSAD on your left hand and IKJL on your right hand. Once you get over the control issues (which is going to take some practice) you'll be an unstoppable rolling machine. Starting with small things around the house, eventually you'll be rolling over small animals, dogs, and eventually people, cars, heavy machinery, entire houses, well... you can see where this is eventually going to go!

This is a great casual game with an enormous amount of replayability thanks to some of the different challenges on each level. And that soundtrack - WOW - you'll fall in love with it and the songs are all genuine earworms.

If you haven't played it, you should. There's nothing quite like this one.

110270063.review:
👎 I want to give this game a thumbs down to help the games ratings because I did not enjoy my experience with it 👎

I'm really glad I finally got to give a Katamari game a go, but I have admit. This franchise is just not my cup of tea.
This game is honestly just so unsatisfying to play. You're constantly bumping into things all the time and losing parts of your Katamari because of how close-knit everything is, and getting jostled and slapped around by all the random things in the world. Or stopping flat in your tracks because something that looks like it should be an add to your katamari, is in-fact. Not. Or things that *can* be, have to be knocked-down to the ground first away from your katamari and you have to roll over it with the janky slow controls, instead of just being added to your katamari.

In-regards to difficulty, I found this game to be quite easy, I only got one gameover during my entire playthrough of the game. But despite it, the game for me is just not that fun to play. I always wanted to play one of these games and roll up loads of stuff because that sounds amazing and fun.
But the reality is, the game is just frustrating exercise in (excuse my crudeness) c*ck-teasing. Whenever you're starting to enjoy something about the game, the game stops your fun right in its tracks with being hit around, abruptly stopping due to being too close to something too big, sloggish controls, and at times poor item pacing.

Another mark against the game is just how awful the king is. He's so incredibly mean that I ended up just skipping all of his text. This game is such a silly, cute little funny fantasy romp through a weird world. And then you get this guy who's openly belittling you, and this is taken to 11 when get a game over (seriously, look it up on youtube). He just spends an actual full F*cking minute just shaming, belitting, and speaking down to you for failing the level. It's truly appalling. I don't see what's supposed to be funny about that, and all it does is serve to completely destroy my mood whilst playing the game.

The music was fantastic, and the katamari art style is still as unique as the day it released. The humor for the most part is pretty funny, but the bizzare humor really becomes stale as the game goes on as they clearly have no new jokes to tell or ways to switch it up.

Ultimately, I don't like this game. At every turn, the game's doing something to completely kill the vibe and mood of the game. And I honestly kind of hate it for that. I wasn't expecting this from a game i've heard so much good about and have been wanting to play since I was a little kid.

(P.S, I recognize that as one's skill increases at the game, I have zero doubts that the bumping problem and abrupt stopping would deeply decline. But for someone who is only interested in playing casually with little regards to paying attention to the size values of everything and all that other stuff. It's just not fun for me.)

107867829.review:
[b]Positives[/b]

+ Weird, unique gameplay involving rolling up objects to become bigger so that you can roll up even more objects.
+ Levels change as you become bigger and revisit them and find objects you can now absorb that you previously couldn’t.
+ Silly, quirky story and setting that doesn’t take itself seriously.
+ Lots of little attention to detail e.g. the katamari changing style and colour to fit the objective.
+ Catchy, fun soundtrack that’ll have you bobbing along to it as your katamari consumes the world.
+ Some really ridiculous objectives e.g. a level littered with bears of many sizes, the first one you catch ends the level but you need to try and catch the biggest you can.
+ Unique controls have you using both analog sticks to control the katamari.

[b]Negatives[/b]

- The controls can take some getting used to due to how unfamiliar they are.

[b]Conclusion[/b]

This is a fun and original game for people who are open to different styles of gameplay and like the quirky setting. The controls are a slightly double-edged sword as they’re unique and help to make it feel like you’re pushing around this ever-growing mass of miscellaneous objects, but also a bit strange so might not immediately click how to maneuver to the best of your capability. One of the main highlights is how satisfying it is going back to a previous area and finding something that had previously been bullying you in your smaller state, like a dog, is now pathetic compared to your mighty katamari and consuming them into your ever-growing mass of things.

This takes me back, way back. Sitting in my little room with a tiny TV with this being about the only game I had. Played by myself and with friends. I absolutely loved this game and I am happy to be able to play it again. 

That being said, I do have a few issues with this port. The keyboard controls are abysmal. A positively charming 3D-sandbox-puzzle game!! Where to start? 
The visuals are bursting at the seams with excitement, colour, and blocky fun! The whole game is just eye candy. Top it off with a boisterous and bittersweet soundtrack, and you're already rolling up a lovely time!

103289212.review:
[h1][i]Katamari Damacy Reroll: Less is More[/i][/h1]
While the original [i]Katamari Damacy[/i] still maintains the inspiring charm and unique beauty that establishes its cult-classic status, [i]Katamari Damacy Reroll[/i] gives the game a well-deserved reconditioning. [i]Reroll[/i] introduces the beloved PlayStation 2 release to present-day platforms and embraces improvements that help [i]Katamari Damacy[/i] reach its full potential. 

Remasters are usually hit or miss due to the inherent awkwardness of updating a video game to suit modern technology. Gameplay changes and the jump to a higher resolution don’t always support the original artistic intentions and technical decisions. Fortunately, [i]Reroll[/i]’s simple image quality upgrade doesn’t only clear up a screen full of clutter—it enhances the overall experience while retaining the original minimalist art style.

Instead of stretching out the image to widescreen, [i]Reroll[/i] maintains the same camera position as the original but provides a wider view, enabling players to experience and engage with more of the complex environment. This extended view also benefits players when the Katamari grows to larger sizes, as it supports a more efficient peripheral for when movement can get tricky.

[i]Reroll[/i] also preserves the original textures from the PlayStation 2 version but sharpens and cleans them up for high-definition. This graphical tune-up makes the game’s visuals much easier on the eyes while keeping with its iconic and intentional low poly looks. Of course, it wouldn’t be a [i]Katamari[/i] game without its fair share of ironic minimalism.

Speaking of minimalism, [i]Katamari Damacy Reroll[/i] is a great example of the “less is more” ideology video game developers take into consideration when remastering video games. MONKEYCRAFT didn’t make any unnecessary or questionable changes that would have strayed from the original version’s themes and ideas—they did all they needed to do and let the rest of the game speak for itself.

99960251.review:
A pretty casual action game where you spawn in an item-filled level and roll around your katamari ball, collecting all items smaller than you and growing your ball until time runs out. There is local multiplayer. The story is mostly nonsense/random. There is some variation in side levels (for example, instead of getting the biggest ball you might be asked to collect the biggest specific object).

If you enjoy this type of game and have already played all the Katamari games, you could take a look at The Wonderful End of the World (which is a Katamari-like game which offers many more levels to play but isn't as polished (for example, you can't see items on the ball)).

Other thoughts:[list]
[*]You can actually see the items you pick up on your ball. When you crash and lose mass, things fly off nearby and you can pick some things back up. 
[*]I wish the camera was more zoomed out.
[*]It feels weird at first but to properly turn you need to hold L-down/R-up or vice versa (if you just hold down-left to turn you'll just move the ball but not the camera so you can't see where you're going).
[*]It only has a few levels. The most reused one is large and it changes where you spawn and the item locations to help make it feel a little different.
[*]Sometimes small things are hard to pick up when you're too big (it matters more on side levels where you have to collect a specific type of object).
[*]You can get pretty stuck in some areas (until maybe you lose enough mass to escape).
[*]The most frustrating part was the 'collect the biggest bear you can find'. Since the level ends when you get one it gets pretty frustrating when you accidentally run into a random tiny item, a small one runs into you, or you get hit by a car and ricochet into one and have to waste like 20 seconds to retry the level. I'd much rather have it where you can discard the item (with at worst a time penalty) and continue playing (until time runs out).

99147819.review:
I've been a fan of the Katamari games from the beginning. Following the previews in PSM leading up to its release, and finally picking up that odd little budget title at Best Buy when it came out (the clerk was very confused as to what the game was, I told him I'd heard great things). I have a fondness for the games that will never fade, so I was pretty excited to give this new port a shot. I say "port" instead of "remake," because, beyond minor visual improvement in a select few areas, this is straight-up the same game we got in 2004, warts and all.

Don't get me wrong, the problems in the original aren't deal-breakers by a long shot. It was to be expected for such a new game concept. But the sequel, [i]We Love Katamari[/i], ironed out virtually all those issues. The physics were much more forgiving, and generally it didn't penalize you for being in the wrong place at the wrong time. Going back to the original can almost feel like the game engine is just a prototype. So in "Reroll," I was expecting at least some quality of life improvements from [i]We Love Katamari[/i] and [i]Katamari Forever[/i], but instead it plays exactly the same.

Not only this, but new visual and audio bugs/glitches can be found in this version. Yes, they tend to be minor, but it's pretty bad to see it in a lazy port that bills itself as a remake.

That said, if you're a fan of the series, get it. If you like weird Japanese games, get it. As much as I don't want to reward Namco Bandai for the extreme laziness of this port, it's still a fantastic game, and I'm still holding out hope for a [i]We Love Katamari Reroll[/i].

98538999.review:
[h1]KATAMARI DAMACY REROLL[/h1]

Rating: Good
100% Time: 20~ Hours
Genre: Unique
Quick Summary: A game where you have to roll up objects into a ball in a certain time limit. While the controls are god awful and can't be changed, the huge amount of charm will have you strangely addicted....as long as you remember the game is not supposed to be frustrating. 

[i]Positives[/i]
[list]
[*]Everything about the game just oozes charm and love. The character designs, the settings and the overall craziness of some items really enhances replayability
[*]Every single item (1400+) has a section in the collection guide with a brief discriptions which are often actually quite funny.
[*]I know the game is fairly old, but the gameplay is simply unique. I don't think anything has ever been done like this even until now. Katamari Damacy has such unique gameplay and there isn't any other game I can think of that even resembles it's gameplay elements.
[/list]
[i]Neutral[/i]
[list]
[*]The game is fairly short; you can complete the entire game in about 5 hours. It's also VERY easy. This is totally fine because it is meant to be leisurely but I did think there was more to the game.
[*]The achievement list goes both ways. 19 of the 20 achievements are very easy and can be done just by beating the game (as well as another one that requires you to get a few extra items), while the final achievement which requires you to roll up every item is so time consuming and frustrating i'd go so far as to say I wouldn't recommend this game to completionists.
[/list]
[i]Negatives[/i]
[list]
[*] The controls suck, and I honestly think that is objective. The controls are straight from the PS2 version which is....fine, but it's almost impossible to play this with a keyboard. I played with a controller and I spent all 20 hours wrestling with the controls. They're kind of hard to explain but the biggest gripe is that there is no camera control. Instead of the left stick moving and the right stick being camera, both sticks do the same thing: rotate your character around the ball. In order to move you have to use BOTH sticks, and then have one stick to move your character around the ball while the other keeps the momentum. If you want to change directions you almost always have to come to a complete stop, move your character around the ball then start again. It sucks. I know this is the way the game is designed, I know there are "purists" that insist the controls are perfect but no, they aren't. You either will get used to them or you won't. The fact that is even a topic means objectively their bad. Good controls means everyone will eventually get used to them. Some might say "well you're just bad and you suck!". This game does not require you to be good. I was able to accomplish everything and get 100% while fighting with the controls so there is no point in debating whether or not I was good.
[*] You can't really remap the controls at all because the control scheme is so brute forced you just have to play around it.
[*] The game starts in windowed mode the first time. Alt + Enter didn't work to full screen it for me and you are instantly thrust into the tutorial and you must complete it before you can even access an options menu.
[/list]

98461209.review: I mean it's a Katamari game... you roll a ball around and collect everything you touch into a ball to make celestial bodies. 98461125.review:
Katamari Damacy is silliness and frivolity incarnate. Its soundtrack is made up of songs which take the katamari so seriously that it wraps around itself like some sort of ouroboros of absurdity, making everything twice as nonsensical. The king, your guide to this world, is the very definition of  flamboyance and quite rude to boot, perfectly introducing you to the task at hand. 

Amongst all the ridiculousness, Katamari Damacy also doesn't shy away from the sinister nature of the mission in front of you. You'll be rolling up random debris, people, and buildings alike in your effort to replace the cosmos. So anything that can flee will treat you like the kaiju you are and, as they often fail, the katamari quickly becomes a writhing mass of terrified limbs, rolling around to the beat of peppy pop or a chorus of children. There is a contradiction of tone inherent in this experience that 'mood whiplash' cannot even begin to describe.

The same could be said about the game itself. It runs perfectly well on a modern system and has a distinct enough visual design to avoid looking dated. However, dated is exactly how I would describe the settings menus. Reroll is more of a port than a full remaster and so, exactly like the PS2 original, all of its settings are tied into the hub planet which you won't see until after the tutorial. That means you'll likely be playing through that tutorial in glorious windowed 1280x720. You'll also need to exit a stage to save, check your collection, or adjust sound levels and you need to fly over to a whole other planet to choose a new stage, triggering a short cutscene every time. It's certainly an inconvenience, but compared to the joys of playing Katamari from the comfort of my own PC, it is a truly forgivable slight indeed.

96850992.review:
[h1] What is a video game? [/h1]

This question is very hard to nail down, as games can be so take so many forms and be so many things. The simplest way to consider this question is by determining one game as a point of reference. When thinking of a case study for all games, many would look to classics such Super Mario Bros. or The Legend of Zelda. Others would consider modern yearly titles such as Call of Duty or Assassin's Creed to be an evolved form of what video games are.

However, all of these answers are rubbish, so I will make the statement here and now that Katamari Damacy is [i] the [/i] video game. If you want to understand the core of what makes games fun, play Katamari Damacy.

96841063.review:
Well, let's say sort of recommended.

Kalahari Damacy REROLL is a perfectly good game while it lasts, but there just isn't enough of it for the $30 price tag. There are only 10 main stages and a handful of challenge maps (i.e., the same stages with specific goals like "roll up as many crabs as possible"). Despite having only played a tiny bit of it years ago, I was able to pass almost every level on the first try. It didn't take more than a few tries on any level before I was close to the size limit. The challenge maps are harder, but sometimes have annoying conditions like "roll up the biggest cow you can find, but don't roll up any other cows before then".

Kalahari Damacy is a pretty unique and fun experience, but I'd wait for it to go on sale if you want to get your money's worth.

96215059.review: A slightly upgraded port of the legendary surreal game from the PS2. Katamari could best be described as a casual puzzle game, but applying a genre label to this game is very tough.  The scale of the game starts small, rolling a sticky ball around a table on a small room, and eventually leads to surprising heights. The main lure of the game is a rolling sense of humor.  Each little object, creature, or environment is inherently silly and arranged in bizzare ways that keep driving you forward.  As you collect the camera slowly and subtly pulls out, objects that were daunting before suddenly get absorbed by your Katamari and by the time the the timer is ticking its final moments you look around you and see how far you've come.  This majestic afterglow continually comes after EVERY level. The timer is a little aggravating at first, but you'll soon appreciate it  as it carves these experiences into finely tuned portions to prevent you from engorging yourself on its content. Buy it as long as you have a gamepad.

It's not very often I pick up a game and just can't stop playing until I'm finished, and that was the case with this. 
I originally bought this game for a nostalgia trip, since I played a bit of Beautiful Katamari as a kid on my xbox 360, and found that game to have a banger soundtrack plus some really fun, satisfying gameplay.
Now, don't get me wrong, this game is in almost every way less innovated, the menu music is super loud at first and high key annoying to me personally, there are less levels that are recycled a lot, some of the custom challenges are really annoying (cows and bears), the transitions and graphics are obviously less smooth...

I absalutely loved this game. The music was overall, a real banger just like the first, the gameplay and controls are solid,  and It's still so terribly satisfying. All the satisfaction you may have gotten a little glimpse of playing those little dumb io games on mobile or online from getting bigger and consuming more is very well fed in this game. I am floored at the care to level design and just how fun it is to PICK UP THINGS WITH A SPHERE. There's always something going on at every corner of the map, and it always feels like there's that next thing to move on to. While I did say that some of the custom constellation challenges were annoying, all the other ones were fun and a nice change of pace for the normal game. I was actually really impressed and thrilled to do the last one (The north Star), and if you've read this far I'm just gonna leave that one a surprise to you ;3

95359366.review:
My, Earth really is full of things. 

The original Katamari Damacy is one of my favorite games of all time. The charm, the humor, the music, and the frantic gameplay all come together in such a perfect package. I’ve played this REROLL remaster on the Switch just recently and I also just played through it on Steam because I’m a sick freak. One of the weird technical problems with this game is the Names listing in the Collection mode being weirdly laggy in both the Steam and Switch versions. However I can say that I believe Katamari Damacy is one of those games that everyone should experience at some point, be it in its original form, or the REROLL version, which is really little more than a rerelease. And that’s just fine because the core game is so thoroughly enjoyable.

I purchased my PS2 and a large bundle of games from a garage sale one warm summer afternoon at the height of puberty for $100 even. I had known a PS2 lot was being sold at this particular garage sale because I had scoured the neighborhood listings in the days prior. So when the seller saw that I was oddly prepared to make this exact transaction, she asked if I had seen one of the postings about the sale. For some reason I said that no, I had just happened upon this sale, suggesting that I often ventured out with only a one hundred dollar bill and an empty backpack on my person. I don’t know why I said this. But that was fine, because there were plenty of nuttier people around town for whom biking was their main mode of transport, such as Crazy Bike Guy, who seemed to do nothing but ride around town everyday shirtless no matter the season or weather. One time I saw him in the middle of an intersection picking up and smashing his bike on the ground. But anyways, after I made the purchase I gleefully rode back home, trove stuffed in my bag,  

Among the titles were each incarnation of Grand Theft Auto available for the system, BLACK with its bullet casing-riddled boxart, and a host of indistinguishable Tom Clancy games. Katamari was not among the lot, BUT it didn’t take long for me to pick it up from the local used game store, now deceased (rest in peace Jonny Cee’s). I will say this was a time in my life when I was very unhappy with myself. It was great and still is great to have a game that really is just pure distilled joy. Today I’m unhappy with myself for many of the same reasons, if not quite as angsty. But I digress.

Even if things are just things, they still have their purpose. There is a time and place for everything. You wouldn’t guess this at first glance playing Katamari Damacy, which relishes in the excess of materialism. On the surface the game world is littered with anachronistic objects, but closer up they all have some sense of order to them. They may be part of some little vignette somewhere within the organized chaos. The cosmos are in chaos too. When you restore the stars to the sky you may wonder if the end result is really better than what it was like before. But that’s okay. Things often have an order and purpose to them even if it doesn’t seem like it from a distance.

A dual stick controller is necessary for this game. The controls are unique and may take a while to get used to. This really is the only downside to the game and can be a significant hurdle to overcome, but it’s worth it and the controls do make sense. The gameplay is nonstop kinetic action as you roll around your little ball in the shape of those Covid-19 news renderings. The soundtrack is among the best in video game history. The writing is witty and sharp. There is no greater feeling than when the King praises you for being “so speedy and so smart.” 

A MUST-PLAY, and for me a near-perfect game.

94924070.review:
[h1] Summary [/h1]

Katamari Damacy ReRoll is a fine enough port of an underrated, yet still infinitely relaxing to play classic, and is a perfect introduction to the Katamari Series as a whole, with some setbacks affecting mainly keyboard players.

[h2] Introduction [/h2]

I personally wasn't someone who was too particularly familiar Katamari, but have heard about it through the internet. Eventually, I pulled the trigger when I found out that it was on sale for $10, and was delightfully surprised with the amazingly unique soundtrack, simple yet relaxing gameplay, and at times strange Japanese-esque humor. Falling in love with the concept, I made it a goal to 100% the game, and found myself losing several hours to it.

[hr][/hr]
[h1] The Actual Game, Now. [/h1]

The story starts off with you finding out that your irresponsible father, the King of All Cosmos, had gone on a drunken stupor and destroyed the entire starry night sky. He then tasks you with repairing most of it. Fun, simple and relatable. 

Is simple game, yes?

[h2] Controls [/h2]

Then it moves onto the tutorial, where you find out how the play the game. Wow, my first grip already is here, that was quick. This is where many people get confused, me initially included. This probably shouldn't have been forced before the ability to change the options. This isn't a console anymore, the game should've given options to change resolution, sound. etc. 

Regardless, I ask that you stick it out, as it's just one of those minor grips that many have with the port.

This is also the point of the review where I say that...

[b][u][i]you should be playing this game with a controller.[/i][/u][/b]

I played this game initially without it, and came to this conclusion on my own. Despite being a port for [b]PCs[/b], the keyboard implementation is strange and will always be strange, to say the least, since it benefits greatly from analog inputs. It's doable, just weird. Another reason why this PC port is a bit wonk.

You get a choice of Usual Controls versus Simple Controls. I would recommend Usual for those using controllers/gamepads, and Simple for keyboards. This is because keyboards can't use boosts effectively otherwise, and Usual offers more control for controllers. 

Regarding Usual Controls, you roll with both analog sticks in the same direction. It's strangely intuitive and also not, resulting in something that's easy to use but hard to master. I like!

[h2] Gameplay Loop [/h2]

Alright, stick with me now, it's a little complex, so I'll dumb it down.

You. Roll ball. Get small thing. Grow Big. Grab Big Thing. Simple, Satisfaction. BUT!!! Time limit. Hurry Up.

At the end of the level you get to see how much you picked up, and its fun seeing it turn into a star, thus fixing the sky. That's it, and that's all you really need. Hours of fun.

[hr][/hr]
[h1] Minor Grips [/h1]

There are a few, but nothing major. They are as follows:
[list]
[*] Keyboard support is wack. So try to avoid it. I really mean that, since I don't want your first impressions to be hampered.
[*] The weird forced intro tutorial. I've seen people just refund the game from that point, so that probably shouldn't really be there.
[*] The Constellations don't give you anything for 100% them. They are the hardest challenges full stop, and are great fun. Atleast the Shooting Stars gave you a show. I still did it, anyhow.
[*] Getting Shooting Stars and 100% Constellations don't add up to the 100% achievement. [spoiler]Also 100% credits don't do anything either.[/spoiler]
[*] It really is very short, and I can see for some the game being a bit pricy. Please get it on sale for atleast 50% off, it goes on often.
[/list]

[h1] Conclusions [/h1]

Very fun and relaxing. If I could get this game on mobile I would absolutely play the hell out of it. Please give it a shot if you ever have the chance!

[h3] Additional Note [/h3]

My Katamari Record is 875m 52cm, beat that!
Also Comment below for any questions, I'll try to answer.

94170659.review:
[h1]INTRODUCTION[/h1]
Katamari Damacy Reroll puts you in the role of the Prince, son of the King of All Cosmos, tasked with rebuilding the stars in the sky after your father accidentally destroyed them all. You begin by rolling a minuscule ball around and rolling up items to make it bigger and bigger until you eventually reach colossal sizes over the course of 19 levels. Please ignore the screaming of the hapless citizens and animals you rolled up along the way, those are tears of joy!

This is a port of the original PS2 Katamari Damacy and my very first time playing one of these games, like many other reviewers I would be very excited for more ports of the other games in the series as I would love to experience them as well. 

[h1]VISUALS & AUDIO[/h1]
Just from looking at the preview images for Katamari Damacy, you’ll probably be able to tell whether the artstyle is for you or not. I’m sure I don’t have to tell you how colourful, vibrant and charming this game is to look at. The visuals are simply timeless and it’s blocky, cartoonish style is just as appealing now as when it was initially released back in 2004. 

The soundtrack and sound design are as equally charming as it’s visuals. With an eclectic and memorable track that could stand on its own and was clearly composed with a lot of love. The sound design adds to the whole experience as well, giving you useful audio cues and playing into the game’s lighthearted charm.  

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]
The majority of levels task you with rolling up your katamari to a predetermined size, preferably exceeding that goal before a set time limit. In order to do this you will need to collect objects at or of a smaller size to your katamari, allowing it to gradually grow and collect larger objects. You will have to avoid colliding with animals and larger objects as crashing into something will cause items to fly off your katamari reducing its size. However there are seven constellation missions with unique challenges, but I won’t spoil them here. Instead I strongly recommend you try them out for yourself. 

While it may sound quite simple, and in a way it is, it's an excellent puzzle game and overall a great experience. If I had to summarise this game in three words it would be quirky, infectious fun!

The controls are quite unique, emulating the feeling of pushing the katamari with both hands. On a controller this is done by pushing or pulling on both joysticks and on the keyboard you’re given two sets of 4 buttons for each hand. You will not need a mouse for this game. 

Admittedly the controls aren’t very intuitive on the keyboard and I found that my fingers would start to hurt if I played for an extended period of time so I strongly recommend that you use a controller while playing. This was originally designed with the twin-joystick controller in mind and I can understand that they intended to replicate that feeling on the keyboard but as I’ve already said it’s a little clunky and not explained very well in the tutorial. Still I wouldn’t say it’s broken and it’s entirely possible to play the game without a controller, so it’s up to you. Either way, part of the fun is in practising and mastering the art of katamari.  

An additional minor warning that I forgot to give a friend before they bought the game was that it loads straight into a tutorial in windowed mode and is very loud at first. Both these things can be adjusted after the first level but you can also adjust your volume mixer if you don’t want your eardrums blasted out in the opening of the game. It’s just a small thing and won’t affect the overall experience but I feel that it’s worth mentioning. 

There is also a local multiplayer mode that allows you to compete with friends. That said, I haven’t played it for myself but I’ve seen examples of it online and it looks like a lot of fun. If they ever port the other games to Steam I hope they’ll add an online feature as I’d love to play with my friends from across the world. 

I completed all of the levels in about five hours but 100% completionism builds from there and the levels have a lot of replay value. I’ve heard there’s an eternal mode where you have free reign over the levels with no time or size limits and I’m looking forward to unlocking them and going wild. 

[h1]CONCLUSION[/h1]
If any of this appeals to you then it’s time to get the ball rolling. Don’t worry, do your best!

94166567.review:
Man, this had an original premise, one which certainly made for a memorable game. It's a lot of fun. It's amazing starting the level small but then getting large enough to collect entire skyscrapers in your Katamari. There's a fantastic catchy soundtrack to go along with it as well.

I'd recommend it, but keep in mind that it's quite a casual experience, only taking me five hours to reach the ending. For those looking for more of a challenge, there's a bunch of extra stuff left to do afterwards. I'm not usually one for full completion though, so for me it was just the right length.

I had never played a previous Katamari game before, so it took a bit of time to get used to the controls. I feel that they could have made them easier, but I got the impression that this was by design, probably making the game too easy otherwise.

The PC port is a bit half-arsed. You're locked in to 30 FPS for one. You're also forced to play the tutorial in windowed mode, only being able to reach the options menu until it’s finished. To be fair though, due to it being a remaster, rather than a full remake, it may have been too difficult to fix the former issue. It's just jarring to play nowadays, but thankfully, it remains playable though.

93521337.review:
tl;dr: Katamari Damacy REROLL is a decent recreation of a masterpiece.  So should you get it?  Despite the flaws, it's a great way to experience the game, but I would recomend you just get the original PS2 version if you have a PS2.

What can I say about this game that hasn't been said.  Katamari Damacy is one of those games that really brightens the world.  It's artstyle, music, and gameplay make it one of the best experiences out there.  It was cool to see it remade for a bunch of platforms.

Katamari Damacy's gameplay is the most charming and fun thing about it.  It's easy to understand, and somewhat difficult to master.  Properly controling your Katamari requires not pushing the analog sticks all the way in a direction, which requires a bit of forethought.  But the game itself is incredibly well made, with barely any gameplay issues in this or the original PS2 version.  It's quirky and absurd, but charmingly heartwarming.  Some of the levels can be frusturating, but the absurdity makes up for this.

Graphics are relatively unchanged, despite raising the texture quality and putting the game in HD.  The models for objects are simplistic and blocky as they were in the PS2 version to save memory, but it's charming style has stuck with it throughout the entire series.  The worlds are humorous.  You often roll up to strange situations with no context, and the devs made built objects out of existing objects.  The context is also absurd, and the cutscenes are hilarious.  It's a game that defined the indie titles to come.

The music is not cannot even be described as legendary.  That's all there is to it.  It's beyond legend.  Every song in the Katamari series is one of the best things to cherish your eardrums.  The soundtrack consists of a large variety of J-pop, jazz, and more experimental melodies.  Most of the songs' lyrics are in Japanese, which to me makes the game feel more authentic rather than translating everything for the rest of the world (coming from a guy whose only anime exposure is Ghibli dubs, this says a lot).  The varied musical styles and rhythms grab the heart and will not ever let go, "like a curse," as the composer put it.

But the remake... has a lot of work to do.  This game has some questionable design choices.  For instance, you can't put the game in fullscreen during the tutorial, or ajust graphics settings during gameplay.  You have to be in the hub.  The game also has no autosave, requiring you to save in the hub.  The game doesn't even give you the option to save when you close it!  You have to go to the data section of the hub.  Keyboard controls are pretty bad.  I'm okay with this, since the game is designed for a controller, but it would've been nice if they put more thought into non-controller methods.  Finally, they took out endless mode, which was the best part of the game, letting you get your Katamari as big as you wanted with no time constraints.  That irks me in a pretty bad way, because I first experienced Katamari Damacy through endless mode on my cousin's PS2.

Overall, Katamari Damacy REROLL is a decent recreation of a masterpiece.  So should you get it?  Despite the flaws, it's a great way to experience the game, but I would recomend you just get the original PS2 version if you have a PS2.

93092612.review:
i’ve always been a huge fan of the Katamari series, there’s so much to love about it: you roll around a ball and collect objects off the ground to grow in size in quirky and unique levels with an OST that has never gotten old. if you’ve never played a Katamari game, there’s a few things you should expect with this remaster in order to have the best experience possible. 

this truly is just a remaster of the first Katamari game in the series; there’s no new content or levels, just the same old game with refined graphics and PC accessibility. Katamari Damacy is also fairly short, it only takes a few hours to complete all of the available levels (assuming you do them all in one attempt)

as much as i love the Katamari games, the [i]biggest issue[/i] i’ve had with this game is the glitchy and frustrating physics that come up when you reach larger sizes in-game. i found myself getting frustrated with how often my katamari would get stuck between two objects and begin rapidly losing size in an attempt to free me from the tight crevice, or the katamari would struggle to get past a tiny obstacle/slope and the small impacts would be enough to crash objects off of it and lose my size. this issue was also present in the original game as well, but just keep in mind that you may struggle with mobility in some parts of the game.

despite those issues, i still had a great time replaying all of the levels and rolling the world into a big ball! i still adore the music and art style, it brought back many old memories of when i used to play KD on my PS2 as a kid. definitely give REROLL a try, but perhaps wait for a sale, and make sure you play with a controller for the most authentic experience!

I've been playing Katamari since it released in 2004 and I regret paying full price for an attempt to capture a piece of nostalgia.

WARNING: MOTION SICKNESS ALERT!

I must say, in about 20 years of videogaming I very rarely suffered from motion sickness due to videogames, or motion sickness in general even. Katamari Damacy Reroll is one of the games that keep causing it constantly, thus ruining my "gaming sessions".
At first I thought it could be my problem, but with a quick research I noticed that many different sources reported the problem with this Reroll edition. The same is not true for the original Katamari Damacy, meaning that there must have been some problems in the rework.

Now, the game is really really fun and has a great soundtrack. During the two sessions I played (1 hour total) I had a blast, I just wanted to keep playing. Problem is, I couldn't, because the motion sickness starts kicking in after 10 or 20 minutes.

In short, the game is unplayable for me (and apparently several others) and I wouldn't recommend it at all. Just play the emulated version from the PS2.

92194756.review:
This game is my first experience with Katamari. This is the game I would have and wished I grew up with.
The objective of KDR of literally rolling up everything in sight and turn them into stars is unique yet addictive, chaotic yet charming, mischievous yet innocent. The controls were a first time for me but I got into them really fast.
 I couldn't get enough of the game's unique vibrant colorful visual designs from cute and funny character designs to a fun lively menu segment. 
There's a time limit for every level but the time amount granted is really generous which I like since not only you have to beat the level's main objective with plenty of time to spare but also go back to levels for exploration, beating your score and rare collectables.
The game's OST are new to me, there are crazy mixes of Japanese pop and I love them, I easily jam to them in my car. The songs vary instrumentally from each other but sure are toe tapping. Some are bouncy and energetic listening to them during a level will make you hysterical as you roll around and around. Some are also slow sweet gentle tunes like the menu screen where you just want to listen to the strumming guitar and hums as you watch the prince walk around in his home planet.
I wish I could keep singing praises for KDR but there are a couple of things that bother me and made playing for me a struggle, especially fir completion.
One was the controls. Now I love moving around with two analogue sticks it's unnatural any other way, but the controls are really bad for me when I had to dash, climb or quickly move the camera. I could do them fine but losing time and items was almost inevitable for me. I'm not sure if Steam version is at fault, the game was like this since the PS2 or it could just be me.
The other thing is that you lose your items way too easily. When I hit a wall or was pushed is not bad since it's my fault but when I got stuck, had to climb for items or lots of things pushed me at once I ended up losing 10cm to 20cm worth of items. Whenever I collected anything rare I had to be extra careful and watch my katamari to make sure I don't drop it until I was home free 
I didn't mind these faults during my initial play, but they were an annoyance during my completion run, turning the fun collection hunt into a struggle and a chore.
Overall, I really adore and had a good time with KDR. This is the game I would have easily loved, cherished and played during its PS2 era. It is different but sweet and inviting for anybody, there's no other game like it with lots of things to offer, even if you'renot Japanese. I really hope more Katamari games will be coming to Steam. I'm really looking forward to that time.

91735219.review:
This was one of the quirkiest and enjoyable video games I have ever played and I had so much fun!  A worthwhile experience IMO for anyone who views video games as a form of play and fun and desires to add novel/unique/fresh experiences from their gaming.   I knew of the Katamari games from PS2 era of games (2004), but I never got a chance to play any of them during those times.  What a joy it was to get into it just now, although I regret that I have been so late to the party.  I also really enjoyed the Japanese pop music that accompanied the gameplay which I assume represents the 2004 era. 

As the game was originally released in 2004 there are some nostalgic flashbacks such as cassette/CD players, oldschool CRT TVs and other household goods of the times as you run them over with the Katamari to make your Katamari bigger to then roll over more stuff to get bigger and bigger. This game also definitely feels like it’s a game from Japan and I think that is part of why it was so charming for me. 

I’m real glad the game has found its way to me on PC. It’s something I missed out on that I wanted to play but didn’t have the means back in the day and have since completely forgotten about.  Performance wise it never crashed on me and it ran well with practically zero load times.  The dual thumbstick controls to navigate the Katamari took some getting used to, but after about 4-5 missions I go the hang of it.  A tiny annoyance is that on first run, you are forced to complete a short tutorial of a few minutes before you can access settings to change the game’s resolution and make it full screen.

PS: My biggest Katamari was 828 meters!  :D

91618234.review:
"Buenos dias! Have you ever been to Spain? It’s Our other homeland. We hope you can visit during the day’s rolling. Like that’s possible. Oh, yes. Almost forgot. A Royal Review for the hardworking Prince. That’s what We were getting when We lost it on Earth. Wallet, keys, rings, hopes and dreams. We lost it all. Must be around somewhere, so roll it up while you’re at it."

Katamari Damacy is a game about the 5 centimeter Prince of the Cosmos going to Earth and collecting as much things as possible to recreate the celestial bodies his father, The King of the Cosmos, accidentally destroyed on a drunken bender through space! Whoops! How will you collect those things you ask? With a Katamari of course! As Fred Durst once famously said: "Keep rollin' rollin' rollin' rollin'" 

As you roll up more and more things, your Katamari will increase in size, which will allow access to more of the stage, and the opportunity to roll up even more things around you. This creates a very engaging puzzle like loop of navigating the stage to avoid the larger hazards, all the while keeping in mind the location of those hazards for when you're big enough to get your revenge and turn them into a star. My biggest gripe with Katamari Damacy is collision can sometimes be particularly devastating, and send many of your hardrolled objects all over the place! Couple this with getting STUCK in certain places, and you're liable to see many, many, MANY(!!!) items go flying off your Katamari while you helplessly attempt to get unstuck and cease the losses. I encountered this many times on my playthrough, and while it is frustrating, the levels are forgiving and usually quite quick. This problem was remedied in the sequel We Love Katamari, and I can only hope they release a REROLL of that as well! Check it out!

91423068.review:
Remastering Katamari Damacy was a lovely gesture by Namco, and I'm a fan of the new, slightly more cartoony aesthetic that closely matches the cutscenes.

Unfortunately, Katamari Damacy is vastly inferior in every conceivable way to its sequels, We Love Katamari (PS2 exclusive) and Beautiful Katamari (X360 exclusive). And I don't mean minor improvements here; we're talking Assassin's Creed 1< 2, Red Faction 1 < Guerrilla levels of escalation. More missions with more mission types, larger worlds, more maps, better load fidelity, far better balanced time limits, interesting side characters, switchable characters, collectables, everything. 

Those two games are what I grew up with, and playing them back again today, I can assure you there are no nostalgia goggles involved with their shining quality. I gave up completing this halfway through, because my only two thoughts while playing it were "Damn, this is where it all began" and "This game has utterly nothing to offer that I haven't seen done better". A more sensible thing to do would be break the console exclusivity with the two consoles and bring remastered versions of [i]those[/i] to PC. 

That might sound harsh on the original here, and don't get me wrong, it was a groundbreaking idea nicely executed. But it's obsolete, and unfortunately no amount of fresh paint can fix that. You'd be better off buying a copy of We Love Katamari and an entire PS2 to play it on (or, you know, an emulator). That said, I want desperately for Katamari Damacy's legendary sequels to be shown to the PC crowd, so maybe buying this will incentivise that? 

I don't know, do what you want, but don't say I didn't warn you as you sit there in this game's empty levels, having hoovered up everything with five minutes to spare contemplating existence.

91023203.review:
I would have a hard time coming up with a solid list of games I would consider to have absolute perfect game design, but I know for sure Katamari Damacy would be on there. Despite how antithetical Katamari Damacy may feel to our collective perceived notions of videogame conventions and norms, Keita Takahashi still managed to tap into that same escapism primeval soup that characterizes so many of our favorite games, abstracting its violence to a family friendly degree while maintaining its appeal and utilizing it to create one of the most cathartic power fantasies in the medium.

What’s truly brilliant about KD is how much of its chaotic and free form nature ends up dictating its narrow and tightly focused design by default without resorting to any hand holding or pushing the player in any particular direction beyond the main premise of rolling a ball over stuff to make it bigger. Its progression naturally unfolds before you, as you increase the scope of your katamari and more things become available to be consumed by it, immediately a consequence of every choice the player makes in their unconscious toddler rampage. And whatever frustration that might arise from its more clunky mechanics and physics is quickly subverted when you finally get big enough to roll over that annoying bear that would always stop you on your tracks.

Funny then how that stroke of incredible originality and genius seems to have sparked by mere accident from just approaching video games from an outside perspective and being dissatisfied with the industry’s modus operandi and never taking itself too seriously. The final stage that beautifully represents the apex of the experience unveils the artifice of the game in its final moments, showing that you have been playing in a playground all along, and that recess time is over, the self indulgence was fun. Pardon my boomer-ism, but it’s a major bummer that we probably will never return to an age like the PS2 gen where people like Keita Takahashi get the opportunity to take the wheel and produce a unique title like this one that sits nicely next to its big budget pals.

It might come across as corny or histrionic of me, but the feeling I get while playing Katamari Damacy is one of love. This is a labor of love, a life affirming appreciation of all things that encompasses our planet, and while it does have something to say about consumerism or capitalism, it does it in a humorous and non condemning way in the same vein as Jacques Tati would with his films and without ever sacrificing the joy of rolling up everything on sight as people scream and a cheerful jazzy song plays in the background. Katamari Damacy is above analysis or interpretation, it is an achievement of ludology, up there with the likes of Tetris, and you don’t have to question where the art is because you can see it right in front of you, and you can play it. Truly a lonely rolling star in a sky filled with static dust.

90615283.review:
There's a lot about Katamari to like. For casual gamers, the progression of going from tiny to massive is rewarding on its own. With the unlockable endless modes, moseying around and collecting things at your leisure is one of the best feelings. I have personally done the final Endless mode several times as a way of relaxing. The way that you can come back to the area you started in with a fresh perspective on what is now obtainable given a new size is always a design mechanic that I think is incredibly appealing. No matter where you start growing, or what level you're on, it always feels like there's a new goal to roll towards.

I have also gone ahead and finished all of the achievements in the game. Most of them are pretty simple, only requiring you to complete the standard levels, which you'd do to finish the game normally anyways. Two achievements are notably harder though. The collect all presents achievement is challenging since they are usually hidden, and the King of Katamari achievement literally asks you to grab at least one of the 1400+ items in the game at least once (120 or so of which are fairly to extremely difficult). If you're looking to 100% the game, I'd get very used to the sight of cows and bears, since you'll probably be resetting those levels about 60 times wondering how you touched that tiny object that resembles a bear or cow. You will definitely end up redoing all of the levels several times over to get all achievements. If you're an achievement hunter, this will definitely be a tedious undertaking, but will definitely feel rewarding after you've successfully gathered everything. I'll definitely still be rolling around, even after 100%ing the game though, couldn't recommend harder.

Katamari Damacy has amazing level design. If something is a barrier in the early game, you will be back to roll it up in the late game. You play on the floor of a house in the beginning, pick up everything in the house in the middle, and pick up the house itself in the end. Katamari Damacy has satisfying progression and great payoff. Does it still stand up 17 years after release? It is still fresh and amazing.
